Sometimes you just don't see it clearly in front of your eyes because flashy editing from Evans are smart enough to present what should be seen or not without losing any meaning of it. "Hardcore" music scoring from Aria Prayogi and Fajar Yuskemal successfully brought the audience into silent mode for most of 101 minutes intriguing action with less predictable twists along the way.Even though the budget is fair low, approximately $1,1 million, it is effectively spent into every department of the movie. Basic storyline, however, outplayed by convincing choreography from the casts. The Raid is a non-stop action from start to finish, let the final battle alone is near flawless. Absolutely impressive to keep audiences on the edge of their seats, even still breathless when the credit titles rolling. A must-see in the cinema to feel some rare "vibrant" experiences. Respectful Evans has deliberately sent the message towards international viewers that lesser-known Indonesian movie industry is about to change in the next few years.http://databasefilm.blogspot.com

Serbuan Maut - The Raid: Redemption – CATCH IT (B+) Ever since The Raid premiered on various festivals all over the world. The buzz surrounding the movie was increasing day by day. Finally now I got the chance to see Malaysian blockbuster The Raid: Redemption. This is a story of a SWAT team becomes trapped in a tenement run by a ruthless mobster and his army of killers and thugs. The main protagonist of the movie is defiantly its brutal and fast tempo action. Where other movies have a strong story and dialogues, the raid covers those things with brutal action. The action sequences of the movie are so well choreographed and shot that not for a second you feel like it's getting too much. There are many moments which will literally makes you jump of your seat. The performance by all the actors is good considering the genre. In the end, it's a highly entertaining movie and even non action/violence lovers will enjoy the movie immensely.

reviews.review_title: Electrifying action, stunning choreography -- great action movie
reviews.content: Director and writer Gareth Evans shows his incredible gift of action filmmaking, demonstrating solid martial arts choreography, spectacular gun shootouts, and a stellar plot in this inventive Indoenisan action thriller. The Raid: Redemption follows the story of Lieutenant Wahyu who leads a S.W.A.T team of commandos on a no-holds-bar mission to raid a twenty-story apartment building in search of a vicious drug kingpin named Tama. Fighting through an army of gangsters. The team find themselves faced with overwhelming odds as they left fighting with limited ammunition and use of incredible Martial arts skills. This intense film features the cast of Iko Uwais, Joe Taslim, Donny Alamsyah, Ray Sahatapy, Yayan Ruhian, and many others.Action has been among one of my favorites genres in Hollywood. The action genre has come a long way with films like Die Hard, The Rock, Face/Off, The Matrix, The Bourne Identity, and the recent Mad Max: Fury Road. This foreign films is a rare action thriller that shows a textbook example of how action flicks should be done. The action sequences consisting of intense and bloody gun shootouts and electrifying martial arts fights are incredible and exciting to sit through. Baring some resemblance to the fight scenes in 'The Matrix', these scenes display some outstanding choreography, and the camera-work done by hand-held camera is quite striking as it captures the pure intensity of the scenes instead of bloating the action with ridiculous shaky cam that many action films suffer from. The final fight scene during the last fifteen minutes can easily be held as one of the greatest fight scenes ever put on screen. The plot also works pretty well and remains intriguing for most of (if not the whole) thanks to its powerful pacing. The character on the other hand, could use some improvement. Iko Uwais's character is decent and solidly written as well as Ray Sahatapy's character Tama, the drug lord who the SWAT team pursues after. The rest of the characters lack depth and little to nothing to known about them other them being elite SWAT members. The Raid: Redemption is one of the best action films I have seen in a long time, and a film every action fan must see. It is very fun and pulse-pounding to watch, and there is never a dull moment. However, the film is definitely not for the squeamish as it gets extremely violent and bloody from start to finish. This is best indicated by one of the film's tag lines "1 minute of romance, 99 minutes of non-stop carnage".

reviews.review_title: Non-stop, edge of your seat action: The Raid is THE definitive action film
reviews.content: 2 hours of non-stop, jaw-dropping action. The choreography of Serbuan maut (2011) is a sight to be seen; how they made this film will always elude me. Simply put, this is the definitive action film and maybe the best martial arts film ever. Awesome!

reviews.review_title: Incredible action from an unlikely source
reviews.content: Hong Kong and Japan have supplied us with some of the greatest action packed movies ever. The stunt work can be incredible and the whole artistry astounding, it's almost a ballet of violence. To my surprise, from a very unlikely source comes 'The Raid'. Filmed in Indonesia with full cast from there also (albeit directed by a Briton) this more than matches some of the best from the previously mentioned countries.A group of heavily armed police are sent into a tower block to bring down the well armed and prepared godfather. The gangs loyal to their master are more than a match and it's a battle to the death, with survival and escape as great importance as the original mission.The action is heavily violent and you will wince at points. The martial arts can be astounding to watch with great choreography. The lead characters also despite their star roles are never primadonnas either, which is refreshing.This is one strong movie. Excellent non-stop action with a good story. Everyone in the story was amazed by how it all flowed and even applauded the film at points throughout. It was that well made.Brilliant film and I'd highly recommend this to any action fans.

reviews.review_title: One of the best action movies
reviews.content: The Raid is one of the best action movies ever with a simple and effective premise that's extremely intense and thrilling throughout. Iko Uwais gives an incredibly committed lead performance and Donny Alamsyah and Yayan Ruhian are both great. Gareth Evans' direction is amazing and it's superbly filmed with visceral and breathtaking action sequences. It's expertly paced and the music by Mike Shinoda and Joe Trapanese is excellent.

reviews.review_title: One of the most astonish Indonesians martial arts action film!
reviews.content: The Raid: Redemption (2011) is one the most astonish Indonesian martial arts action film I have ever seen. The most Action films I have seen were are Hong Kong action films with Bruce Lee, Jet Li and Jackie Chan. But this movie completely surprised me. The movie is delivered in perfect Die Hard-Jet Li's Meltdown (1995) style - (and the John Woo- Hard Boiled Style) -- you'll see lots of martial arts, gun plays, axes, knives and machetes. The stunts are completely insane in scale. The film is violent, and very gore bloody full action movie!!!! I haven't seen that kind of action martial arts film in any cinema. The most martial arts Hong Kong action films are from the 80's and barely 90's, but in 2011 there was this astonish Indonesian perfect martial arts action film. The violence the blood, the gory and action everything is perfect.The movie starts fast paced, entertaining with a plot story, you can go in to the story without hesitation and you are hooked up on the seat.A SWAT team takes it upon themselves to bring down a highly crime lord; the team enters a 30 floor apartment building in the middle of the ghetto where the crime lord is known to operate from. Once the SWAT team makes it to the fifth or sixth floor, the crime lord learns of their infiltration. The lights go out. The exits are blocked. Only then do we realize that the inhabitants of the apartment building are lethal gangsters, hit men, crazies and cop-killers. The crime lord speaks briefly into the building's intercom: kill these unwelcome visitors- be sure to have fun doing so- and be rewarded. Then all hell breaks loose! The fighting sequences are expertly choreographed and insanely realistic. You can actually feel the pain of the people getting their bones snapped like twigs. And the pacing and editing of the movie is simply phenomenal. Think of it as Tarantino bloody violent action film! An elite swat team has to fight their way through an apartment complex-turned-safe house full of Indonesia's most dangerous killers and gangsters in order to take down the notorious drug lord that runs it. From start to finish, I was on the edge of my seat, awestruck by the brutality and bloodshed that emanated from every scene. In the end, you're not going to walk away talking about how memorable the characters were or how well-developed the plot was. No, you're going to walk away feeling entirely breathless, almost as if you just got smacked upside the head with a shot of pure adrenaline. This is the kind of movie that doesn't pull any punches. It goes right for the gore and only gets more deliriously wild and intense from there. If you're a huge fan of action flicks like me, I urge you to watch "The Raid: Redemption". Yes, it's a foreign film with English subtitles, but believe me, it's well worth seeing. It's a slick, deranged, no-holds-barred astonish action seat movie, that'll knock your socks off and leave you speechless.This movie kicks ass! Iko Uwais as Rama police officer member of the SWAT team kicks ass and the fight scenes of no hold barred are astonish and very fast paced realistic.The only problem with the film I do have and why I gave it a 8 is because: there was a less shootout scenes, I was excepting more shout outs and used more automatic gun plays and hand guns. I was excepting the movie would be more mixed martial arts action film in a John Woo's---Style Hard Boiled, I was excepting more explosions not just one. Mostly I wanted that only one member of the SWAT team survives and not three, that would be perfect just like in Die Hard. I wish Rama would not had any help by fighting Mad Dog (Yayan Ruhian) with his brother Andi (Donny Alamsyah) if those scenes would be cut the movie would have been much better and I would gave it a perfect 10. That Rama would have killed single handily drug lord leader Tama (Ray Sahetapy). I was also excepting that Tama would fight more with Rama not that he would be shot in the head by Wahyu (Pierre Gruno). At least that is my problem with the film that is why I prefer the sequel The Raid 2: Berandal (2014) over The Raid: Redemption (2011) because it had everything in it, that I was excepting in this film, it was in the next sequel film.The positive things about this film is that he saved Bowo (Tegar Satrya) and he arrested Wahyu (Pierre Gruno) and he did not killed them, he saved two people including his brother.Anyway this movie is what it is, a perfect 8, because it takes the vision of one of the most imaginative directors on Earth, and realizes them almost perfectly with all the tools that fit the task -- actors, stunts, puppetry and martial arts choreographer.The Raid: Redemption (Indonesian: Serbuan Maut, meaning The Deadly Raid; also known as just The Raid) is a 2011 Indonesian martial arts action film written and directed by Welsh filmmaker Gareth Evans and starring Iko Uwais.8/10 Grade: B+ Studio: PT. Merantau Films XYZ Films, Celluloid Nightmares, Sony Pictures Classics Stage 6 Films Starring: Iko Uwais, Joe Taslim, Donny Alamsyah, Yayan Ruhian, Pierre Gruno, Tegar Setrya, Ray Sahetapy Director: Gareth Evans Producer: Ario Sagantoro Writer: Gareth Evans Rated: R Running Time: 1 Hr. 41 Mins. Budget: $1.100.000 Box Office: $4.105.123

Legendary Indonesian action movie about a group of heavily armed police storming a mobster stronghold building. It does not go according to plan.It's non-stop intense action all the way. Very fast paced and entertaining. A simple plot but an extremely well made movie. Martial arts and camera work are amazing, although gets a bit martial arts overload in the end. Good movie.

reviews.review_title: Even after 10 years, this still remains one of the best martial arts movies that I have ever watched.
reviews.content: I have decided to run down the memory lane with "The Raid". It is one of those movies that I always suggest to people that are into action, but they would like to watch something different than the usual blockbuster. Gareth Evans here achieved greatness in terms of choreographies and fighting scenes and remains in my humble opinion one of the greatest movies of its genre in recent years. There are interesting and unusual camera angles, lots of experimentation and absolutely beautiful fighting scenes that simply you can hardly beat. This film is very gruesome, it is not scared to show raw visuals, as it should be. Practical effects are amazing and the sound design is always on point. There was a lot of creativity and passion involved in this project. For sure this film left his mark and even after 10 years, it is still an extremely valid and unique production that sets a really high bar.

reviews.review_title: ABSOLUTELY BRILLIANT & PROBABLY THE BEST ACTION MOVIE EVER MADE!!! THE BEST FIGHT SCENES EVER IN ANY FILM...EVER
reviews.content:
WOW!!! The Raid is full on frantic action-packed & exciting, probably the best Martial arts film ever & possibly the greatest action movie ever made!!!This gritty as hell, bone crunching cops vs criminals action Thriller is mind blowing with it's in your face fighting & brutal action.
This is Adrenaline-fuelled violence with stabbings & shootings all around in a grungy criminal infested Tower block of danger!!!
I can totally see where the BRILLIANT Dredd got it's setting from.This has the best fighting scenes I've ever seen in any movie ever!!!
This also is also actually scary with it's intense situation & savage Machete wielding bad guys, the whole situation of a team of cops going to raid a crime lords huge apartment block that's full of enemies is so exciting & intense i absolutely loved every second of it!!!This is action cinema at it's absolute best, move over Expendables all you need is the fantastic warrior Iko Uwais, this guy is warrior who puts Jet Li & Jackie Chan to shame!!!
Iko is a good actor who uses his intense face to show what's happening & he's excellent but also equally great is his police team leader Joe Taslim, this guy can fight & has one of the best fights in the movie when he goes up against the evil unstoppable Mad Dog!!! The camera angles captures every blow & stab it's outstanding film making thanks to the excellent director Gareth Evans.The setting of the tower block is an intense & scary place full of danger.The Raid is an action packed MASTERPIECE of action cinema!!!

A Powerhouse brutal crime Action Thriller & believe me it's Thrilling!!!

After reading many good reviews about The Raid I had high expectations for this Indonesian martial artwork. I'm a big fan of the first Ong Bak and this one exceeded Tony Jars masterpiece in my opinion. The story is clearly designed for one purpose: To be able to put as much action into this epic as possible (it's not the most original, but hey, who cares?!). The choreography is beautiful, cinematography over the top (so creative and still always on point), the editing is astounding. I've watched a lot of martial arts movies but this one made me feel the pain more than any other movie I've ever seen. You know the feeling when your body twitches with the action? Yes, it's THAT good! I'm throughout impressed by this and command the writer director team! Indonesian cinema isn't the most popular but this movie puts it on the map. Can't wait to see more like it!

After seeing The Raid 2 I had to see the original and it was great. Seriously, it is because of movies like this that one can feel confident that martial arts movies are progressing in the right direction.The story unfolds at a nice even rate keeping the viewer waiting for the finale where we will understand exactly how far the characters will go for whatever reason they give us. The truth is though we don't care so long as there's plenty of lethal violence and blood shedding.The Raid Redemption is a very cohesively constructed and portrayed story full of action and adventure, an absolute joy to watch. A must see for any martial arts movie fan. It's basically martial arts porn and beautiful porn at that.

reviews.review_title: Intensely violent action covers for clunky plotting and a surprising lack of tension
reviews.content: Marketing is a strange beast; the goal is to get everyone talking about your product, getting excited about it and making the effort to see it. As a viewer though this can be counterproductive because sometimes the hype can overwhelm expectations and produce disappointment when the film turns out to be only "good" and not the most amazing thing ever made. With The Raid I think I may have got caught up in the hype because I did make the effort to see it whenever I got the chance and was very aware of the many gushing reviews and claims of being greatest action movie for decades etc – in fairness it is hard not to be disappointed when this is rattling round in your head and sadly I was a little disappointed.I'll start with the negative aspects. Firstly, although the plot makes for a very punchy and simple one line pitch, it does still manage to be unnecessarily messy and has aspects that it throws in with surprisingly clumsy touches. Rama having a personal interest in the mission is just announced without much in the way of explanation is one example but so are other narrative devices; OK this is a film where plotting isn't perhaps the most important aspect, but this should have made the job easier and make these clunky aspects all the more annoying. As writer Evans owes a debt to other films for the structure and concept but unfortunately he hasn't managed to capture an atmosphere that makes his film stronger. Films like Die Hard and others have used closed environments to really elevate the tension outside of the action sequences, but here I don't think Evans really manages to do it. Early in the film perhaps, but it is not sustained and as the action really kicks off it does lose a certain feeling of urgency.Although these weaknesses exist, fortunately the film does really deliver when it comes to excessively violent and brutal fight sequences. Evans sits back off the majority of the action and doesn't resort to rapid editing to make it seem fast and furious – in this case it really does feel intense and impacting without using this device. The martial arts is impressive but it is all the better for being brutal, furious and full of pain for everyone involved; while there are moments of individual violence that made me winch and look away, generally the level is about right because it constantly reminds us that this is an intense fight for survival and helps us forget it is just a film while we are watching. The cast impress in this regard and in particular I like the sequences with Ruhian, Uwais and Taslim in action. As actors perhaps they do not quite come up to standard but still they command the screen when it comes to the physical action.Overall, The Raid is an enjoyable martial arts film with plenty of brutally violent and engaging fight sequences that cover for the weaknesses in storytelling and atmosphere. If you go in full of hype these weaknesses may seem more important than they are (as they did with me) but ultimately it is the action that you came for and, as much as I would have liked to have more of an atmosphere through the film, it is here where the film generally delivers.

reviews.review_title: Plays out like a violent video game with attackers continuously piling out of apartment rooms as characters move through various floors (levels)!
reviews.content: 'THE RAID: REDEMPTION': Four Stars (Out of Five) Indonesian action/horror film teaming director and writer Gareth Evans with star Iko Uwais (the two also teamed on the 2009 Martial Arts action film 'MERANTAU'). Like their first collaboration this film is filled with fight scenes featuring the Indonesian Martial Art pencak silat, choreographed by stars Uwais and Yayan Ruhian (who plays the villain of the film). It tells the story of a rookie SWAT team tasked with bringing down a viscous mobster residing in a fortress like apartment building, protected by drug dealers and killers. The movie is extremely violent and dark but it's also one hell of a thrill ride. Action and Martial Arts fans are sure to be delighted.The majority of the film is set in an apartment building in Jakarta's slums. It houses some of the most vicious and ruthless criminals and killers in the area and their lead by mobster Tama Riyadi (Ray Sahetapy). A rooki SWAT team is assigned to enter the building (that even the cops are afraid to step foot in) and bring Tama to justice. What they don't know is that the mission has been put together solely by the corrupt Lieutenant Wahyu (Pierre Gruno), with his own agenda, and no reinforcements will be sent in to assist them if needed. Tama knows this and surrounds the building with his thugs trapping the police inside to be killed one by one. A battle ensues as the film focuses on one strong willed Muslim cop named Rama (Uwais) as he struggles to survive the onslaught of death and carnage.Like I said the film is graphically violent and gruesome and the tone of the film very much leans towards the horror genre. It also plays out very much like a violent video game with attackers continuously piling out of apartment rooms as characters move through various floors (levels). It's a little too dark for my taste but it is a fun ride nonetheless. The fight scenes are brilliantly choreographed and the action is spectacular. Of course none of it is the tad bit realistic but movies like this aren't supposed to be. It's a visceral ride, a very violent one at that. The director and stars are sure to move on to bigger and better things and the film is already set for an American remake and two sequels!Watch our movie review show 'MOVIE TALK' at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xh674mS5vTo

Most of people who were unaware of Iko Uwais will follow his every film of the past and future once they end up watching this movie!! This movie relies and is driven only on action and action only.The movie works because of many reasons. one.. it is pure commercial modern action flick which doesn't give room for any drama or lazy moments where we don't look at screen and stare at the person sitting to our left or right..it simply captures you from the very beginning and till end. Second..The story works in favor of the movie and a damn good screenplay keeps the audience in its grip. I think Hollywood production companies can take some serious money management lessons on how to make decent and entertaining movies without spending too much. As far as i know this movie has been shot in a very small budget not because of the unknown cast but because of the sensible direction and treating the script accordingly and not experimenting with the basic rules of action cinema i.e. you deliver or go make drama...!! The camera-work is great and fighting sequences has been shot beautifully and you don't feel that you have missed anything at all in those fight scenes. Also actors have done a superb job and you will see that the movie overall is better then you contemporary Hollywood action flick...!! Many action scenes will drop your jaw. Though the highlight of the movie is the final clash between Iko Uwais and Yayan Ruhian who stole the show with their stunt choreography but other actors and stunt men have also done a superb job. Mike Shinoda has done a great job with the background score and it add sparks to the whole action sequences.Gareth Evans has done a good job in Direction as well as in Editing also.There is a lots of scope in Asian cinema..and people who will see this movie they will realize how much more Asian cinema can offer them they just need the right people willing to invest in their projects..it is not just about HK or chines or Japanese cinema there is much more to be explored yet.What Tony Jaa flicks like tom yum goom and ong bak did to Thai Movie Industry..The Raid will do to Indonesian Movie Industry.I think this is the best action movie i have seen in this year so far and i hope i will see the sequel very soon!! Though there will always be better movies but despite its limitations it delivers So this is a very entertaining movie and a treat for action fans.my rating 10/10..A Must Watch.

The Raid: Redemption is an Indonesian martial arts action film, and a great one at that. This movie is already considered by many to be one of the best action movies of the decade and it shows why. The Raid is essentially a video game made a movie. It's cops vs. drug dealers in a building, and each floor the difficulty is increased. The plot is simple, yes, but for the sake of the film, it really doesn't need to be much complicated. My only complaint with the movie is sometimes they try too hard to make the characters deeper, showing some of their past and misfortunes, but all it does is stall the movie. But The Raid has some of the best action sequences I have ever seen, it is brilliantly choreographed and some of the camera-work is pretty good. Excellent action flick!

Well, there are actually some quite helpful Youtube channels when it comes to movies in that they actually make recommendations for films that tend to slip under the radar. This is one of those films, and the fact that it came out of Indonesia is certainly one of the reasons that I wouldn't have heard of it, nor would I have thought of actually watching it. Another thing is that it appeared on the SBS streaming service in Australia, which meant that when it came around to watching an SBS film, I pretty much took this one straight away.So, there is this building in the middle of Jakarta which happens to be controlled by this gang and it is basically impenetrable. However, the cops decide they want to take it down, though there are suggestions that things aren't quite above board, especially when the boss suggests that cops can be bought where as rival gangs need to be dealt with. Well, when I say that it is impenitrable is certainly is because the cops get taken out pretty quickly, though a handful survive, and they realise that they need to get out.The entire action pretty much takes place in the building (though there are a couple of scenes outside), so you could say that this film follows the unity of time, place, and action. Well, there is an awful lot of action in the film, and I certainly wonder how they managed to make this film without half of the actors actually getting injured. In fact, I suspect that there were an awful lot of injuries in this film - it certainly is nowhere near as tame as some of the American films that you tend to get.The other thing is the martial arts. At first I thought that this film was simply going to be a lot of machine guns going off, but the thing is that the cops that do manage to survive end up without any weapons, so they need to resort of their fists. In fact, I never expected an Indonesian film to have such hard core martial arts in it, and this movie certainly doesn't let you down in that regards, especially as you get closer to the end.Yeah, this film is pretty cool, especially if you really like your action, and have been yearning for some of that old school Hong Kong action which certainly seems to have gone by the wayside of late. I can't necessarily say that Indonesia has picked it up, but with this being the first Indonesian film that I've seen, I have to admit that I really like what has come out. It also reminds me that sometimes some of these movie recommendation channels on Youtube are worth checking out, especially if you want something slightly different to the norm.

Simple story..... the police try and take down a crime lords tower block.
The action is unbelievable, imaginative and goes at a frenetic pace.
If actions your thing you won't want to miss this.

reviews.review_title: Don't let the subtitles put you off, you'll miss out!
reviews.content: This is not the type of film I would usually enjoy. With its cast of unknown Indonesian actors all speaking their native language (I'm not a big fan of subtitles), budget of 1 million dollars and an unknown writer/director my initial thoughts were 'this can only be bad'. How wrong I was and I have my brother to thank for ensuring I saw this groundbreaking piece of cinematic history. This movie has hands down the most brutal, violent and bone- crunchingly realistic fight scenes I've ever witnessed (and I've seen them all!). But what is a great fight scene if the story is weak and/or we do not care about the characters? Gareth Evans manages to tell us what we need to know without meandering or time-wasting and gets on with the business of making a great action movie. The characters are all easily recognisable after a short period of time and you find yourself routing for them (people cheered in my cinema!) when they are involved in combat. The villains are fantastic and are beautifully crafted as the monsters you want them to be. Interestingly they are more than a match for our heroes, which makes for very exciting viewing as you never quite know who is going to come off best from an encounter. This movie is very special indeed, it has shown that in a cinematic world of big names and big budgets sometimes all that is needed is a little talent. No doubt Hollywood will be all over this and will make a remake staring Tom Cruise or Sam Worthington. My advice to you is to watch this first and see a truly groundbreaking, original and damn exciting movie - the likes of which I can assure you you've never seen before!

The Raid Redemption is an action movie directed by Gareth Evans and stars Iko Uwais, Joe Taslim, Ray Sahetapy, Yayan Ruhian, Donny Alamsyah and Pierre Gruno.This is what you call a pure action movie, lots of bullets, lots of fist fights, lots of super fast paced action scenes, lots of Violence, gore and blood. If you go into the script of the movie you'll find none but when you'll come to the action scenes of the movie you will find the movie spellbinding.The movie start on a positive note and after just 20 minutes of the start of the movie you'll understand that you are going to witness a pure joyride filled with action scenes, though being an action movie the gun fights is there but no usage of explosions, bombs and grenades and what you'll witness is fighting with knives, swords, punch to punch, fist to fist and hand to hand.The screenplay of the movie is very fast paced and keeps you engaged throughout, there are very less to minimal dialogues in the movie hence you can expect the amount of action scenes you are going to witness in the movie. The climax of the movie is somewhat disappointing and you'll feel the movie incomplete.There was not much scope for the acting and you'll understand this after watching the movie. But the action scenes in the movie is very superbly choreographed.This movie is a pure fast paced action movie and will keep you engaged throughout. If you are a action movie lover then this is the movie for you. A must must watch.

reviews.review_title: very good of its sort, but of little interest if you don't like martial arts
reviews.content: A SWAT team of 20 police officers enter a seedy apartment building with the aim of advancing to the top floor to take out a crime lord. Things do not go as planned...This subtitled Indonesian movie does have some bits of plot scattered among the combat sequences but, let's be honest, anyone going to this film is almost certainly going to be going because it is an action movie loaded up with martial arts combat sequences, mostly featuring Iko Uwais. Let me state that if you don't like this sort of movie, then you are going to hate this one. If you do, then you are likely to enjoy it, because the fights are as good as any I've seen. And where Bruce Lee's fights were all about grace and Jackie Chan's were all about humour, the fights in this one are all about trying to kill the other guy.This movie is violent and brutal. I don't recall ever having seen another film which had 14 doctors in the closing credits, but I can quite understand why they were necessary.Very well directed, by the way, by a Welshman.

reviews.review_title: It doesn't matter coz you're gonna die soon anyway.
reviews.content: I saw the 2014 Raid first so I knew what to expect. It is brutal, ruthless and terrifying. Because I knew what to expect it was more terrifying. It reminded me of the start of Saving Private Ryan in the apprehension it evokes. It is exceptionally well acted and the suspense is unbearable. I challenge any one to watch it all the way through without once having to turn away. I like the lead actor very much. Uko Uwais is a fine actor and athlete. Mad Dog is very charismatic and also played very well by Yayan Ruhian. These Indonesian actors are great at what they do and amazingly physically fit. The screenplay is very tight and the cinematography is often breathtaking despite the appalling violence. Gareth Evans is a very fine movie maker. Some of the techniques used simply demand your respect. The pulsing sound indicating impending evil is far more effective than scary music too. The way Evans keeps you in suspense through such horrific scenes is awe-inspiring. Martial arts and the fetishistic violence is definitely not my thing but good cinematography is my thing and I would like to see Gareth make some other kind of movies. The suspense is riveting. The look of fear on the hero's face puts tingles up the spine. You flinch at every blow and the sinister ambiance is brilliantly evoked with such lines as "I'll go call the neighbours. You have visitors. You know what to do" (spoken by the boss villain). The timing is superb. Hollywood despite its frequent gratuitous violence tends to sanitise things; much in the same way as Americans say they are going to the bathroom when they mean they are going to perform a bodily function. Bathroom? Really? We non Americans have a shower in the bathroom. That sanitising tendency extends to movies where the shot people lie conveniently and un-confrontingly dead or more typically miraculously absent from the scene. In these Raid movies they moan and scream and wriggle around on the floor afterwards. It lends an air of realism, even in these fantastical scenes of epic violence. For example when a dead body is dragged into the lift it leaves a trail of non-blood moisture on the floor. Touches like this although nauseating are at least honest in their unflinching gruesomeness. There is also a lot of black humour in lines like "You don't shoot cops. You pay them." This is an excellent movie. Although I could hardly wait for it to end I could not tear my eyes away. Its brilliant but appalling. NB my spelling is accurate but using the English and Australian system.
If you're an action fan, watch this from beginning to end. It's non stop and Rama is no joke. He's like Wolverine. After this, watch part 2. It's even better.

Exhilarating action film, with martial arts fight sequences that take your breath away (I was exhausted just watching them!), featuring a police raid into a massive apartment complex ran by a paranoid drug lord with an army of dope fiends, gunmen, and fighters ready to attack. Iko Uwais is the featured star, as Rama, a rookie cop with a pregnant wife and a brother (Donny Alamsyah) who is actually working for the drug-lord (Ray Sahetapy). The drug-lord has been expecting a raid sooner or later due to his connections with members of the corrupt police department (he has evidence of these connections, damning to those in the dept who need this information kept secret). Pierre Gruno is a cop responsible for the raid, secretly plotting to secure the drug-lord for his own devious purposes (briefly; it doesn't take long before his sergeant (Joe Taslim) realizes how dirty he is), with eyes on moving up the ladder in his police department, sitting at the same corrupt table as his superiors. Equipped with an army of dirtbags, Sahetapy remains bunkered in his security room at the top of the tower-like run-down apartment complex, using the intercom to talk to his men and the police who aren't killed towards the beginning (when picked off unexpectedly). Included in the mix is Yayan Ruhian, a rather small fellow but a ruthless, extremely fast, and tireless assassin with fighting skills that have no equal (at least not in a fair fight). Yayan's fight with Joe is really amazing to watch and isn't quite a long as it feelsthis is an example of just how vicious and unrelenting a fighter Yayan is. Yayan being able to withstand (for the majority) of a lopsided fight with not only the hero of the film, Iko, but Donny also just further proves how freakish he is. He seems to have countless energy and stamina, a force of nature, this Yayan. Seeing Iko combat fighter after fighter, down countless halls, through rooms, out windows, doors exploding, tables breaking or working as weapons, bodies just twisting and turning, flipping and flying, hands and legs moving so quickly you can barely see them, The Raid: Redemption gets the pulse a raising and adrenaline rising. The apartment complex is like this dilapidated fortress where men seem to be hiding in every room, up the stairs, down the stairs, ready to surface at any moment, with Iko always having to stay alert or else. The brothers reuniting is a nice little subplot, especially considering how one is a cop and the other a criminal. There's a really nifty suspense sequence where Iko and his partner Tegar Satrya are hidden behind the wall of a tenant's apartment as a group of the drug-lord's killers look for them (the use of a machete stuck in the wall, across Iko's face, is milked for all its worth). The ways some of the fight scenes seem to go as one uninterrupted take are phenomenal. The fighters and stunt personnel responsible for these action sequences (when people are thrown into objects, against walls, and to the floor, they look unforgiving, impactful, believable, and painful), along with the choreography and staging of them deserve a round of applause and countless accolades. The setting is a character unto itself, a very dangerous locale for any man of the badge to enter uninvited. What's really cool is that Iko is actually a decent actor, so he isn't just a hire in the film for his magnificent fighting skills but has acting chops as well! When you see a villain lifted off his feet, swung across the room, his body smashing into a wall, with rotted paint chips and dust shaken away, with the final thud to the floor, it is to be celebrated for just how willing some are to sacrifice themselves for our entertainment. What a movie!

Iko Uwais does most of the ass-kicking here, but a lot of credit has to go to Director Gareth Evans too. The Raid is well-paced, edited, and directed from start to finish. You may have to look away every once in a while if you're a bit squeamish, but you won't want to take your eyes off this film otherwise. An action-packed adrenaline rush that reminds you just how much fun a "martial arts movie" can be.Verdict: Watch it.

reviews.review_title: The best action movie ever made
reviews.content:
The title of this review might seem hyperbolic, but when it comes to the Raid everything is. As far as balls-to-the-wall action nothing can compete with this masterpiece, nothing. The fact that it doubles as a peerless martial arts movie is icing on the cake. Whats more it is a work of remarkably tense atmosphere, the apartment complex serving as a veritable pressure-cooker for the nail-biting plot. Are there action movies with better stories and characters? Probably, now if you'll excuse me I need to watch this for the millionth
time.

The plot for this film is fairly simple; an elite group of police officer must enter a tower block in Jakarta and kill the crime lord who has made it his base. The operation will be anything but simple though; just about everybody in the building is loyal to the criminals or too afraid to defy them. To make matters worse it soon becomes apparent that the lieutenant who ordered the raid didn't get authorisation so there will be no chance of back up if things go wrong and they soon go very wrong! Most of the police are soon dead and those who aren't are out of ammunition; if they are to make it out alive they will have to rely on their wits and their martial arts skills.Most action films spend time introducing characters then have prolonged stops for exposition along the way; not 'The Raid' though. After a brief introduction to protagonist Officer Rama and a very quick explanation of who the bad guys were the raid began and once it had started the action hardly ever stopped! This wasn't CGI special effects and exploding helicopters; it was physical action that will leave you wondering just how many stunt men got injured making the film! Writer/director Gareth Evans did a great job bringing the story to the screen; the action is perfectly choreographed and the actors do a fine job. The amount of bloody, bone crunching action means this isn't for the squeamish but if you want your action films to be full on action you are sure to enjoy this.These comments are based on watching the film in Indonesian with English subtitles.

reviews.review_title: One of the GREATEST Action Movies EVER!!!
reviews.content: Pure non-stop action is what this movie is all about! If you are a fan of martial arts/action movies, you must see this whenever you can. The camera angles are perfectly shot to keep you involved in the movie. A lot of times, I felt as if I was right by the actors. The music is perfect and syncs well with each scene of the movie.There is an extreme amount of fighting, blood and gore, and profanity, so I don't think this will be for the kids lol.The story is put together very well and has a few twists and turns that keep you on the edge of your seat.GO SEE THIS MOVIE!

reviews.review_title: Just a full-on crowd pleaser of the highest order
reviews.content: "1 Ruthless Crime Lord, 20 Elite Cops, 30 Floors of Hell"That is the tagline for "The Raid: Redemption", a film that's sold on a straightforward premise (a SWAT team invades the tenement lair of a crime boss, many fights ensue), but never fails to deliver on its promise: an action thrill ride of relentless martial arts insanity and ungodly shootouts. And these are fight scenes that must be seen to be believed. Incredible camera work places you directly in the fight, giving the viewer the authentic feel of being in the room while two (sometimes three) men engage in a visceral exchange of body blows from lightning-fast limbs. Each fight scene strains (often snaps) credibility, as no human being would be able to stand after one of these punishing sessions. Yet there's the main character (you'll know the hero when you see him), moving from one off-the-wall fight to the next, maiming bad guys in groups.But that's what makes "The Raid" so incredibly watchable. It doesn't take long to go from raid movie to superhero film, as the numbers of the SWAT team drastically dwindle, and we're left with the main guy to do all of the ass-kicking. And he does it with a tremendous sense of heroism; we desperately want this guy to succeed and make it out of that building. So the unrelenting violence and brutality are easier to digest when the audience is overwhelmed with the fist-pumping satisfaction of seeing the superhero clean out the scumbags standing in his way. Unrealistic? Yes, times a thousand. But son of a bitch if it didn't make for one hell of a ride.8/10

reviews.review_title: Perhaps the best martial arts film I've seen
reviews.content: I'm probably going to sound like a little kid here but HOLY CRAP! Everything you have heard about this film is absolutely true. The fighting choreography in this is unlike anything I have ever seen. Now I might screw up some of the characters and their names here, but that's only because they are relatively unknown. Iko Uwais is the main actor in this and according to his bio on IMDb, he is a Taiwanese Silat champion and has been studying it since 10. It shows. His skill is eye popping, truly incredible. And then there's the main villain in the film, who I think is Mad Dog. He's played by some dude named Yahan Ruhian. He is just as impressive, if not more than Uwais. Another martial artist named Doni Alamsyah makes up a trifecta of gifted martial artists. The last battle is a three way as Uwais and Alamsyah team up to fight Ruhian. It truly left me breathless and I clapped in the empty theatre when it was done. I don't know how they did it, but if you think you have seen incredible martial arts battles before, this one will put it to shame.The story? Who cares. Crimelords in Jakarta trap a bunch of SWAT team members in a building and all freakin hell breaks loose. That's all that really has to be said because it is the choreography and the fights in the film that take centre stage and it's one of the best I've ever seen.This is one hell of a ride. 9/10

Violence - %^$# yeah. They really stepped it up a notch on the gore when finishing off some of the assailants which gave me a few good "cringe and laughs".The story is pretty much secondary here people so I won't get into that - to be honest we're watching it for the most inventive ways the two sides can inflict death and destruction on each other.The dubbing is predictably bad but bearable. Apparently some of the fight scenes weren't very well synchronized to the sound effects but I didn't really notice.An enjoyable and well made movie for its genre. Assess your girl/boyfriends' squeamishness level before watching.

A freaking masterpiece. 
The greatest action film ever made, seriously. Elite cops vs a building full of guys with guns, knives, machetes and a very mad dog. This must have been my third time watching it. I didn't even hunt it down, came on TV and I had to watch it AND right after watching it I had to hunt down the sequel and watch that too. This is a must watch for any action junkie.

reviews.review_title: if you have fond memories of early Hong Kong movies and 70s Jackie Chan, this is for you.
reviews.content: Filmed in Jakarta with an Indonesian cast and crew this is an undoubted tour de force from Welsh director Gareth Evans. It begins at full pelt with an armed police team going into a notorious tower block inhabited by a motley crew of baddies, all connected, in one way or another with the drug trade and affiliated criminal activities. As soon as the ferocious action begins I am that, yes, I realised this was what the film was about (a clue is in the title) but can this hold my attention for forty minutes? Actually, although the trick here is not to cut to other activity or pause for a romantic interlude but instead to vary the instruments of war. So, from the automatic weapons of the opening we go all the way to extreme hand to hand and foot to foot martial arts and there is little time to stop to think. We even switch heroes to ring the changes and develop the story a little. But it is the fights, varied, fast and wonderfully choreographed that truly dominate this unique film, Not sure that I am ready for the two and a half hour follow up but this is very impressive and if you have fond memories of early Hong Kong movies and 70s Jackie Chan, this is for you.

An inexperienced SWAT team is on a mission to raid a building housing some scary mobster and his goons. Early on we learn that there may be some other motives behind the orders given by the lieutenant. Things go well as they make it up to floor 6. Then they are discovered. What follows is a good half an hour of exhilarating shoot-out/fistfight scenes in which the inexperience will cost the team dearly. Bodies fly all over the place like sacks of potatoes and there are plenty of mean ways of killing.As we get to know some of the characters involved- some good-natured cops, one of whom is related to one of the mobster's captains- suddenly the movie becomes a wild and remarkable martial arts movie as hordes of goons attack the few surviving cops. The movie loses steam at some point but manages to pick it up again as the meanest of the captains is also almost unbeatable in his martial arts skill. The movie doesn't shy away from unfair fights. The mean captain is a tiny tiny guy but he isn't afraid to take on two guys at the same time.The Raid is an outstanding action movie. It is polished and exceptionally well directed. But when it comes to the action, it sticks to proved basics. There isn't lighting trickery, booming sound effects, supernatural wire-work- just lightning fast punches and kicks, and millions of bullets. And these punches hurt, this aren't the gentle ones found in the Matrix trilogy. One just has to see the long list of health care professionals listed in the credits. The story is rather thin and the production doesn't make enough use of it. I think more could have been done with the story. I found the police action shootouts superior to the martial arts action. You do become exhausted of the martial arts fights eventually. The Raid is to Indonesia what Ong-Bak was to Thailand, it could put Indonesia on the map for action movies. Hopefully they'll take advantage of it. Kudos to the entire cast and the director who turned what could have been an average movie into something unforgettable.

Asians get stabbed in the face, neck, chest and skull in "The Raid", an Indonesian martial arts film by director Gareth Evans.The plot? Martial artist Iko Uwais plays a police officer who, along with a small task force, attempts to conduct a police raid on an apartment complex teeming with gangsters and drug lords. Our heroes sweep and clear each level of the complex, until a final showdown with an evil boss and his deranged henchman.The film's by-the-numbers plot unfolds like levels of a video game, but Evan's direction and action choreography help elevate things somewhat. He knows when to slow things down and build suspense, and the film's choreography is often impressive. Unfortunately the film's better qualities quickly get bulldozed by pornographic levels of gore and violence, characters existing solely as ragdolls to be headshotted, decapitated, gratuitously stabbed or bathed in computer generated blood and/or exit wounds. To mitigate the film's baseness, Evans then adds some hilariously sentimental flashback sequences, in which our macho men think about their wives and newborn babies. Two decades ago, John Woo habitually did the same, cutting back and forth between massacres and kids or churches. Woo was a Christian. Evans is a docile family man. Both felt the need to up the ante in contemporary movie violence.4/10 – Nirvana for a certain type of action fan, "The Raid" was shot on a small budget and with a small crew of amateur actors. It would become a surprise critical and box office success. Worth one viewing.

What does a good action movie requires? I'll say two things: good action sequences, and well build characters. You just can't have one without the other, usually we get the first one, but rarely the second. This applies equally to a regular action movie or, in this case, one of the martial arts type. When you end up watching a good action movie you will remember these two things: the action sequences and the characters.In the case of the Raid, you might remember several of the fight sequences, all of these very well made, from the stunt men to the direction and editing. Now here comes the problem, you are not going to remember a single character, and if you do, do you remember their motivations? See, in an action movie, both the good guys and the bad guys need motivations to fuel what they do. You could say this applies to any other movie as well. For the sake of keeping things simple, an action movie doesn't need complex motivations, but at least it needs the most basic ones in order to make us care about what is going on.The Raid lacks characters with motivations, so all we are left with are extended action sequences that go on and on. The movie suffers from this mantra of "more is better" and it throws away proper pacing in exchange for non-stop senseless and aimless action sequences. Is not enough to have people shooting and fighting and stuff exploding, you need something behind the mayhem. The Raid gives us nothing, no character to care about. Every single character is interchangeable.It has become a cliché to say that a movie sometimes looks like a video game, and it's ironic considering how hard many games these days try to look like a movie. The Raid truly feels like a game, one in the vein of those arcade beat em ups like Final Fight, Double Dragon, Cadillacs and Dinosaurs, Streets of Rage and so on. We get a brief intro, usually a girl being kidnapped, we get a hero to choose and there you go, beat everyone on your path. Also, while you can forgive many things in the plot of an action movie, the movie just gets dumb for the sake of it. The bad guy has cameras everywhere, yet he can't pin a single guy, and he sends just a small group of people, none of them with guns. Some have machetes, but why would they want to use that when they could just gun down the few remaining good guys? Oh right, there wouldn't be any fight sequences left. Is like if in Die Hard Hans decided to tell his goons to look for Mclaine with knifes because that's more "honorable" or something like that.If you are an action aficionado you will dig this, no question about it, but i don't think you will remember much of it. Again, the fights are very well done, far better than in Merantau, but the emptiness of the story and the characters will just make you feel that way, empty. It's like a very tasty fast-food snack that just won't satisfy your hunger. Good for a while, but in the longer term, you want something that has more meat to eat.

i really didn't think i would ever rate a movie 10/10. but i'm doing so now without a 2nd thought.the script in nothing special, the dialogs blow your mind. But let me just say this: it's just a real Live Stream looking action movie, no silly slow-motion-zoom-in blood filled intercuts, just man against man until one can fight no longer. and it doesn't stop for a second, no bathroom breaks, trust me.my only problem with this move is that i will never be able to enjoy another martial arts action film again.Now stop reading reviews and go see it :)

reviews.review_title: Probably one of the best action movies I have ever seen
reviews.content: In a world where going to an action movie means expecting terrible acting, predictable plot, lots of special effects(which have come to bore me), and jumpy camera work, this movie is a breath of fresh air.The strength of the movie is that given that none of the actors are famous to a Stallone level, their appearance on screen and shooting is not enough to incite bad-ass and they must work for their auras. There is no character who just seems innately bad-ass and unstoppable(though Mad Dog comes close), you feel a certain genuine struggle to survive in the fights and the characters really do seem to be fighting for their lives.The initial plot seems simple enough, RAID a place and kill some guy. Yet the plot feels unpredictable, at times it seems like an unknown who will survive and what the goal of the whole mission really is, there's odd betrayals here and there that keep it unpredictable.I have not read anything about this movie, but it seems like a very low budget film, with only one mini-explosion taking place and not in a very cliché manner but in one where the characters truly feel overwhelmed and it seems like a last resort. There is no restraint when it comes to gore either, with clear showing of bloody scenes which I tend to prefer.The focus of the camera work is probably my favourite thing in this whole movie, the fistfights in this movie feel raw because of it, there is no endless cutting, jumping of the camera with every kick and punch like we've come to expect.Only reason why this isn't a perfect movie for what its trying to be is the convenient sequential manner with which enemies seem to pop(instead of all at once) and perhaps some odd decisions by characters to not pick up weapons on the floor and later complain that they are unarmed. With the exception of Mad Dog whose character stipulates this attitude.Overall, Fantastic action movie, highly recommended, though its a true action movie, with fistfights taking up a good portion of it, so perhaps people who are looking for more implied action than direct might not like this very much.

reviews.review_title: The Raid, a basic story but incredible action and mind blowing fight sequences
reviews.content: The Raid is a fast paced, brutal and bloody action movie that is choreographed so well, insanely well. My point is that this film have a high level of enjoyment in it, each scene keeps you suspended and entertained. The Raid is about a elite squad that's tasked to infiltrate a high-rise building that's run by a ruthless drug lord, we follow Rama who is the rookie but really the best as he's capable with firearms and his deadliest weapon, martial arts. It's a very basic story but Gareth Evans succeeds in every way and made an amazing action movie, also great directing on his part!The handheld camera technique works well here, the crew and ensemble cast made the film work. It's one of my personal favorite action movies as it truly have everything an action film should have. The crew have really done a good job at making the action feel real if it's the guns or the hand to hand combat, each fight is suspenseful and powerful. The musical score helps with that aswell, making it flow well with the fights and choreography that the stunt coordinator did a magnificent job with.I wonder how they pulled off some things in this movie, like that fridge scene. There's also a fight sequence, a long one with Rama and Andi against Mad Dog. It's totally unrealistic but so good, like bloody great. Superb! I could watch that for hours because of the fight choreography that they had to learn.Iko Uwais is Rama. What a great martial artist and action star, just wow. This was the second time I watched The Raid and I'm still blown away by it, it was better the first time though but 80 minutes of the hundred were 10/10. I recommend it for action fans or martial arts movies.

Gareth Evans said he wanted to make something closer to Assault on Precinct 13 than just another Martial Arts movie. As many young action directors inspired by John Carpenter's claustrophobic achievement, he fails to read the lesson till the end. Admittedly he only wanted to remember how the appropriate directing of half a dozen extras could appear like an army on screen.The Raid starts well with the sense that the building is the main character. As the SWAT team advances thru the first few floors, the movie is a tense thriller. Then the storyline forks, you no longer really care what floor you're on and fight scenes just happen along the way. The choreography is brilliant, the editing is great - save for the final fight which ridiculously last for minutes - but it's not the Assault thriller of the premise, it's only a Martial Arts tournament setting (Hello Bruce Lee).Another big flaw is to show the Big villain and his sidekicks. He is a nice actor but gets too much exposure whereas he should be melted with the building. His evil sense is as ludicrous as that of the Nicholson character in The Departed. And the sidekicks are not actors, they have zero charisma and are not made better by the dull dialogue.If you are expecting something more than a movie with nice fights, skip it.

reviews.review_title: This is a Pure Action Movie
reviews.content: Just became one of my favorite films.I don't know what to say other than, wow! This movie has some of the best action I have seen in a long time. Maybe ever. You can tell this movie was made by real martial artists who knew what they were doing and not only did they choreograph some absolutely spectacular scenes, but the way they filmed it was almost perfect. There is no overuse of shaky cam and there are no jump cuts and there are some really great long takes. The action is well framed, clear, and in the shot so we can see these fighters go to work. The camera work and cinematography definitely was impressive.The main character is set up in the beginning and the film wastes no time and tells us what we need to know so it can get to the point. The main character is badass and ballsy. You understand his motivations and who he is as a person and you can see that he knows he is in danger. Which is what makes this movie so good because it's like we are watching this guy genuinely fight for his life. Although he is the only character that you're really gonna give a shit about. There's not much depth or character development given to many of the characters.But, the action is able to tell the story. In fact, the storytelling within the action is some of the best I have seen. It is absolute carnage and mayhem at its best. The bad guys are given a few establishing scenes to show us they are bad. It's the cliche crime overlord villain. But the way the action plays out really does tell a story. It's extremely hard hitting and fun to watch. I was laughing and enjoying every second of it. There were so many times where I was like "Damn!" or "Holy Shit!" and just loving it all.Overall, The Raid is a really good movie and I recommend watching it. If you like action movies at all then you will love this movie. There are so many awesome fights that I went back the next day after I finished the movie and rewatched a bunch of them. This makes me really want to start getting into some Kung Fu movies. The plot of the movie is simple but the execution is what makes it really good. If you like action movies there is no way you won't find this film enjoyable.The scene where he is hiding in the wall was so well filmed. I was on the edge of my seat.There is a 2v1 fight that very well might be the best action scene I have ever watched.

reviews.review_title: As Close to Perfect an Action Film There Is
reviews.content: The Raid: Redemption is an outstanding piece of martial arts cinema. Iko Uwais has some incredible fight sequences and the action is nonstop. As far as intense fight scenes go, this movie has them in spades. The Raid redefines that a gritty action film is supposed to be. This is the type of film that fans of the John Wick franchise should easily embrace. Absolutely incredible film.

reviews.review_title: This is John Wick on steroids
reviews.content: One of the best action films of all time. Period. The only complaint is that it had to end

reviews.review_title: The Raid Redemption Review: Perhaps the best martial arts action film ever!
reviews.content: Movie: The Raid Redemption (A): Action - Indonesian Positives:The film starts very well and soon after some time, the killer action takes the charge and goes on to entertain till the very last frame. The action scenes are extremely excellent and they were so well crafted that while watching the movie, I opened my mouth only to say "wow" at the best moves!The screenplay is very tight and the editing, razor sharp. It's not stretched at all and you won't even wish it to be shorter, especially if you're an action fan.Iko Uwais impresses big time and fits into the character of Rama. As soon as he comes into his action mode, claps and whistles are bound to make an appearance!The film has everything you would want a perfect action film to be.Plus, there isn't any vulgarity or obscenity as the focus is completely on the action and storytelling. Hats off to director Gareth Evans for that!Negatives:Nil.Repeat value: Absolutely!THE RAID REDEMPTION is undoubtedly the best martial arts action film ever. Actually, I had seen the sequel first and liked it a lot. But what makes this prequel better, despite of the sequel having some even better action sequences, is its complete devotion to action.

reviews.review_title: Raises The Bar for All Future Action Movies
reviews.content: The Raid: Redemption (2011) *** (out of 4) This Indonesian martial arts picture certainly isn't going to be for everyone but if you enjoy non-stop action, violence and blood then there aren't too many better films out there. The plot is pretty simple as a crime lord has an entire apartment to himself and he rents out rooms to the scum of the city. Even the police won't go into this area but that changes when a SWAT team is ordered to go in and take out the big guy. As soon as the police enter the building they're greatly outnumbered and have to battle dozens of thugs to try and reach the top. THE RAID: REDEMPTION is without question one of the best and most memorable martial art movies in a very long time. The film doesn't try to make you cry, make you think about life or change your life. Instead it just wants to keep you entertained and I can't think of a recent action film that had you so glued to what's going on than this one. We go through this non-stop maze of violence with a rookie cop (Iko Uwais) who is about to be a father in a few months so he really has a reason to want to get out of the building. Director Garth Evans does a wonderful job at keeping the film moving at a great pace but the style he brings to the film is something very special. You just get lost during all of the fighting scenes because they're so well shot that you're often wondering how long it took them to get them onto film. A lot of this stuff really does feel as if it would be impossible to get on film so that just draws you in even more. The performances by all are great, the visuals are terrific and the score is perfect. Everything on the technical side is done greatly but the real stuff is the violence. The movie has just about every kind of death scene you can think of as bodies are shot to pieces, cut to shreds and blood flows just like water would in a river. There are some pretty graphic shots here so of course some aren't going to be able to handle it but the craftsmanship is just so strong that even if you don't normally enjoy a picture like this you can still be won over by it.
Watch , for all the fans of crazy , non - stop , martial arts action films !No story to talk about , no acting either ) but what a brilliant fights choreography !!! Stunning !

reviews.review_title: Good action, loses realism near the end
reviews.content: It's Jakarta, Indonesia, and Lieutenant Wahyu invades drug lord Tama's hideout. The SWAT team becomes trapped in the highrise apartment with no backup. Lt. Wahyu hasn't informed his superiors about the operation. Now they must fight their way out all by themselves.This is an eye opening Indonesian action movie. It is expertly made, and superior to most Hollywood fare. The first hour is a no non-sense, serious action, not about pretty boys ab-offs. But the last 40 minutes does turn into kung-fu fighting unrealistic action. The tension is built thru realistic action scenes. There isn't much explaining needed. But the last 40 minutes do devolve into too much hand to hand kung fu fighting. Other than that, this is a serious action movie. A great serious watch.

reviews.review_title: Still the best action film of the decade so far.
reviews.content: With 20 special force members, a drug lord, his thugs, and a raid, The Raid for the most part delivers to its hype, despite there being not much to its initial story.The Raid carefully builds its momentum in the first few minutes of the movie before the first of many combat ensues. It switches between combat to story progression pretty well, slowly unraveling more to the story and its characters than what the viewers initally thought there was. The scenes don't beat around the bush and we're told only what we need to know of the world surrounding the Raid. Action scenes also vary from simply pumping to very intense. A very impressing display of skill and choreography, seeing this on the big screen would only add to its thrill and intensity.The only criticisim I would have for this is as members of a special force / elite cops, and the fact that they were considering this raid to be a big issue, the comrades of Rama (Iko Uwais) seem to lack the skill and preparation that elite cops must have, even if they were rookies. They were doomed from the start when there were moments of hestitation that could've resulted to less of the squad members being killed. Though it's not much of an error enough to change the film's quality. Perhaps the directors really attributed it to how inexprienced the squad was that led the raid to be doomed from the start.Having seen bits of this film years ago when it was still new, the story and action sequences are still as fresh as it was. Probably the only regret I have was not seeing this on the big screen.

reviews.review_title: It's bloody, it's fun and it's bloody fun!
reviews.content: After premiering at the Toronto Film Festival The Raid was hyped up as one of the best action film in a decade. With that hype behind it there was a risk it could have disappointed, but it did not. The Raid is a very entertaining action film that will please fans of Tony Jaa, Bruce Lee and martial arts films in general. Like The Avengers it made of impressive action scenes followed by impressive scenes, the highlight being the hallway fight with Iko Uwais stabbing his way through the badguys. Uwais is a great martial artist but he is not made out to be superhero, people can hit him, he can feel paid and Yayan Ruhian too is also a very talented fighter. The action is bloody and brutal, but director Gareth Edwards not linger or enjoy pain: he gets the right balance to satisfy our blood lush. Edwards uses an instant hand-held style that lets you feel the frenzy of the fights and action, but the fights themselves well shot, well edited and you can tell what is happening in the film. There is no need for shaky cam. At times the film plays like a survival horror with the criminals coming at the police like zombies, stabbing through walls like a slasher villain or jumping out apartments like in the Resident Evil games. The Raid also plays like the Warriors as gangs hunt our heroes for a main guy. The Raid is an entertaining film.

The Raid: RedemptionI first saw Gareth Evans direct in V/H/S/ 2 which I enjoyed his segment in that film. The Indonesian film about a S.W.A.T. team who gets trapped during a raid. The style of the film is different than modern action films. I say that because the fight scenes are not interrupted by anything. No funny one liners, no cut to Megan Fox, nor brilliant scenes of dystopic clutter. Where as an American director might want to emulate their inner Scorsese or Spielberg, Gareth Evans tries interesting mixes of shaky cam close ups, eagle eye, and wide steady cam. The stunt and prop team was phenomenal for this film. People genuinely seem like they are stabbed, beat, and shot. Speaking of guns, the film has plenty of them but as soon as people run out of bullets the film turns martial arts and showcases what Jakarta has to offer in terms of entertainment.The film suffers heavily in only one department, writing. The character development is at the third act. I was glad that there was the first scene to at least make me care about the main character who should feel like a one man army after all that he's done.The antagonist feels like a run of the mill bad guy. The writers make you hate him for the amount of carnage he ensues but he's lacking the complexity any human would have.The sound effects are awesome, each punch is highlighted in a loud thud that isn't cartoon-y like previous generations martial arts films. The music is thematic and adds to every scene. I can't emphasize the music enough to increase the feeling for every scene. The lack of music before a fight builds anticipation and showcases Gareth Evans' understanding of building suspense, Hitchcock style.Verdict: This movie deserves to be seen by those who can appreciate good martial arts. I watched the subtitled version of the movie. I cannot recommend watching the dubbed version, unless you're unable to watched subtitled films.

reviews.review_title: Takes martial arts to the next level
reviews.content: ¨Pulling a trigger is like ordering a takeout.¨The Raid Redemption has gotten so many great reviews that I decided to check it out despite never having heard anything about it. I had never seen an Indonesian film before, heard of director Gareth Evans, nor star actor Iko Uwais, but I was tempted to see it after hearing it won the People's Choice Award at the Toronto Film Festival. At first I really thought this movie was just another Battle Los Angeles where we had nonstop action with over the top gunfights. I'm not really a fan of these movies which only focus on the action and have little plot, but I was really in for a surprise with The Raid. Once the gunfights stopped, the combat became more ferocious involving a lot of knives, machetes, and even hand to hand combat. I've seen a lot of martial art movies before, but this film really set the bar with all those choreographed fights. They were truly amazing and I really enjoyed the last hour of the movie. The Raid is an extremely violent film so it isn't for everyone, but if you enjoy martial arts then you will love this film. Iko Uwais makes any other martial artist look silly as he is really impressive on screen, but so was the rest of the cast. The martial art used in this film is the traditional Indonesian one called Pencak Silat and it's intense. Iko Uwais choreographed the fights himself along with another actor who had some great fighting scenes, Yayan Ruhian. Together they make the film worth watching even though it has very little dialogue or story. There's no time for talking, it's one fist fight after another.Rama (Iko Uwais) is a rookie SWAT officer who seems happily married along with his pregnant wife. We only see them together in the opening scene where Rama kisses them goodbye before going to work. He gets on the SWAT car along with twenty other elite officers led by Sergeant Jaka (Joe Taslim) and are given instructions: They have to infiltrate and raid an apartment building in the middle of an Indonesian slum full of gangsters and drug dealers. Their mission is to capture the crime lord Tama (Ray Sahetapy), but it won't be an easy task because the building is full of loyal free renters who will protect him at all cost. That is why the police force has never attempted to go near that building, but somehow Lieutenant Wahyu (Pierre Gruno) has ordered the raid and is waiting for them near the entrance of the building. Once the SWAT team breaks in, some local spotters warn Tama that the police have entered the building. Tama observes everything through cameras in the top floor and announces to the entire building that whoever kills these officers will be given special treatment. He even sends his two personal bodyguards, Mad Dog (Yayan Ruhian) and Andi (Donny Alamsyah), after them. The SWAT team find themselves ambushed between the sixth and seventh floor with nowhere to run. That is where the action begins and doesn't stop as all these renters keep on showing up while the officers fight for their lives.The plot is really simple, but believe me the choreographed action scenes are really not. That is what truly makes the movie for me: the hand on hand fighting scenes, especially those involving Iko Uwais and Yayan Ruhian. They are a true spectacle. I had never seen a martial art film like this before with so much intensity and carried out for such a long time. The final hour is practically nonstop action. I would never in a million years expect to have enjoyed a film like this, but the fighting scenes were so incredible that I was willing to forgive the poor plot and just enjoy the choreographed martial art scenes. I hear a sequel is in the making, and I am sure I will be watching it to see what else Iko Uwais has in store for us. This isn't a movie I would recommend to everyone, but if you like a good choreographed action movie then this is the film you will want to see because it truly does raise the bar for martial art films everywhere.http://estebueno10.blogspot.com

reviews.review_title: An Exciting Movie for Hardcore Action Fans
reviews.content: Recycling (for the most part) the same actors as Merantau, Gareth Evans second major martial arts flick was a brutal punch to the face when it came out, cementing itself as one of the darkest, most cringe-worthy martial arts films of all time. While I think this movie is good, low budget fun, it's also got a couple problems that overall hinder the otherwise entertaining experience.A large group of cops, including our hero Rama, are embarking on a sting operation. They enter a sixteen story tenement building owned by a crime lord who rents every room to criminals of all sorts. Everything is going fine for a few moments, but soon enough the cops are dropping like flies and Rama is fighting for his life to escape the building's lockdown.The movie is another example of starting slow but building up steam to get to that awesome climax. There are a couple really excellent fight scenes sprinkled throughout from the knife-wielding hallway fight, to Rama fighting three guys with machetes, to the final battle in a small cell against a guy whose erratic martial arts are perfect for a bad guy. It's brutal, it's entertaining, and it keeps you breathless.Here are my gripes, and they really aren't even that big a problem. The shaky camera is noticeable in certain areas of the film, and really annoying. That said, the action still retains its brutality and you don't miss a single blow. I know that shaky cam is a turn-off for a lot of people though, so I figure I should mention it. The other problem is the music. It's got a rock soundtrack that isn't exactly fitting. The Blu-Ray comes with two options, the original soundtrack or a musical makeover by Mike Shinoda of Linkin Park. Even the original music has unfitting rock music for moments that don't need it. When two snipers position themselves, we're assaulted by completely out of place drums and guitar.Despite this, the film is visceral, violent, and one of the most violent martial arts movies you'll ever see.

I am not a massive fan of action films as I generally find them pretty tedious. This film however is so far over the top and so full of action that it really is hard not to be entertained by it. The plot is basic as cops try to storm the tower block home of a well known criminal though it does have a sub plot as to why they are there in the first place. This film is really just all about the action, fighting and bloodshed and that is your thing then you'll almost certainly like this. There are brilliantly executed fight scenes throughout especially the martial arts fights. Apparently The Raid had a pretty low budget so that makes the scenes even more impressive.
