If you are looking for a simple, easy to watch and entertaining film this is almost perfect.

reviews.review_title: A Lot Of Awesome For $1.1 Million.
reviews.content: Just finished watching The Raid: Redemption. You have to switch the audio to the English sound track. When it first came on, it said "Sony Pictures Classic" and I said "This is no classic." Was I ever wrong. Totally in your face. The best fight choreography and filming I have seen in a long time. As even Ms. Vicki said, "Damn !"It's hard to believe they did this for $1.1 million. It's first rate, top to bottom. The head bad guy was a perfect choice. His main fighter was skilled and proud.The filming made the fight scenes nearly teaching video quality. Pretty rare.The blood sprays were off color, but plentiful and well filmed as well.The movie kicks ten butts, I mean, it rates ten stars with me.

reviews.review_title: A Modern Martial Arts Action Masterpiece
reviews.content: It has been 10 years since this action and martial arts masterpiece was made. Iko Uwais and Joe Taslim star in this movie that plays out like a video game. Police in Indonesia Raid a building to capture a mobster but encounter increased peril as they ascend. This one is raw and brutally violent but it works. Garett Evans' filmmaking and fight choreography are brilliant. The film grips you from the first moment and does not stop. I hear Michael Bay is remaking this for Hollywood and I can't imagine it won't be sanitized and watered down. This movie remind you that good storytelling and action transcend a particular language or Country. Simply one of the best. This holds up.

If you like action, then this is the movie for you. It is nonstop action. The story is not the greatest but come on, I didn't go to watch the story. What I did go to see was a lot of action and excitement. And I can assure you I wan not disappointed. Neither were the other thousand people watching it with me. The movie was a world premier and I have told everybody i know who enjoys these types of movies to watch it. A few people who have seen it based on my recommendation have loved it as much as I did. When you watch it make sure you are alert and in the mood to be and prepared to be sitting on the edge of your seat. I guarantee you will be raving about the raid after you see it.

Definitely worth watching once and maybe even again if you've not watched it for a while and you're at a loose end. The action is fantastic and never lets up so you don't wonder about the plot, cliches etc. Just concentrate on enjoying the fantastic and bloody and gory action sequences!

reviews.review_title: video game translated into real life
reviews.content: I must be getting old. after reading rave reviews in regards to this title ( best action movie in decades... sjeez..decades is a very long time, lots of movies)I sat down with anticipation. And I grew up on a steady diet of Jean Claude van Damme movies and all the copy cats, so my former education in this genre ought to be sufficient I guess.I am not going into the plot,basically there is none and what there is is just a letterhead to get people into confined spaces where they can beat or shoot or mame the crap out of each other. When watching this movie my thoughts drifted away to another movie which had the same sort of rave reviews ( Laid to rest 2) which I also found a bit of a letdown. A completely different type of movie and genre ( this movie is far better made then laid to rest 2 will ever hope to be), but the same type of reviews promising - in that case- wall to wall gore. The problem I see with these type of movies is that there is no plot to speak of, just stages like in a video game where either a masked killer with a big knife ( laid to rest 2) or a guy who is REALLY good in kicking people asses gets into situations where he can do just that..again, and again, and again.Its in a sense like a porn movie compilation, you leave all the not needed tidbits out and go right to the money shot, and put as much of those as you possible can into the running time.Its a tiring experience to watch, and yes the main character - and basically all those involved- show an athletic skill that is off the chart but it gets repetitive..there just so many ways you can hurt someone with your bare hands, gun or knife. there is a parallel to the porn movie example I made somewhere here but I wont go into that.And what I sensed after an hour or so is that I just didn't give a crap anymore who was beating who to pulp and I completely lost interest by the time the two good guys were beating up one bad guy who didn't get down even after getting a healthy portion of a light bulb stuck in his neck; talking about dedication. there was a feeling that the director also lost track of the proceedings because before I knew it they entered the liar of the main bad guy without to much resistance and the movie was basically done( rather literally because it was announced that every bad guy could go home because the show was over??) I read in another review that this was comparable to John Woo's hard boiled and that is in a way correct, although Yun Fat Chow has a lot more charisma then this main character and the character development was on a level you actually gave a crap what happened. And that is saying something because John Woo is no thespian in the plot department.Of all the external reviews I found the one from Mr Ebert the most of my liking in the way that his experience was the same as mine.So is this a bad movie, not really, just get the right mindset and go with the brainless, plot less flow..and be amazed what people can do when trained in martial arts with their bodies and with other peoples bodies.

"The Raid: Redemption", director Gareth Evans' sophomore effort, is a knockout. Featuring some intense, high-stakes action sequences, "The Raid" succeeds at delivering thrills. In turn, it establishes itself as one of the finest action films ever made.As the film begins, we are quickly introduced to rookie cop Rama, whose wife is pregnant with their first child. We soon learn that his S.W.A.T team has been assigned to take down one of Jakarta's most ruthless crime lords. The elite group of cops quickly (and silently) begin to raid the crime lord's apartment building, but they are soon discovered and one exciting, extended action sequence unfolds before our eyes.For starters, the film is captured perfectly by some impressive camera work, which always helps to keep us in the midst of the action. The background music also adds to the tension and is never distracting. The editing is also top-notch as well, which is unlike many of today's action films. All too often, the editing in these films will slack and the action scenes will become an incomprehensible mess. Thankfully, that is not the case in "The Raid."The film's only weak spot, however, is its plot, which is a bit half-baked. As a result, there is minimal character development. Despite this, the cast still does well with their roles. However, the story isn't what made us watch "The Raid" in the first place. It's the fight scenes that caught our attention, and boy, do they deliver. Throughout the majority of the film, we witness gunfights, martial arts showdowns, and brutal takedowns. Expertly choreographed, the action scenes are viscerally intense and highly entertaining. Our hero Rama (Iko Uwais, operational driver turned actor), is the star here and he delivers throughout, dispatching thug after thug using the Malaysian martial arts technique "pencak silat".All in all, "The Raid" is one of the best action films ever released. Despite a mediocre plot, it succeeds at delivering thrills with its impressive camera work, mesmerizing choreography, and brutal and relentless action scenes. It might not appeal to everyone due to its intensity and carnage, but for action aficionados, this is sure to be a treat.9/10

When I read that THE RAID was one of the best action films to come out in decades, I didn't believe it. I thought it was all a lot of hype. I'd heard that sort of thing before and ended up disappointed. But I can say honestly that this is NOT one of the best action films I've in decades. It is THE best, hands down.It's just extremely well done. There are so many amazing, tense sequences in here. I can't even begin to list them all. But the action is nonstop and feels very realistic. There is also some very good camerawork. The acting is good and the story is good, but it's really all about the action here. And even if you don't like subtitles, don't worry. There isn't all that much talking for most of the movie and you won't even notice it's subtitled after five minutes. Highly recommend.

reviews.review_title: Mad Max.. How about Mad Dog.
reviews.content: The Raid is a definite crowd pleaser. Fans of violence, martial arts and pure Adrenaline action, look no further! I'm giving this one 10/10 simply for its awesome fight scenes alone.

"The Raid: Redemption" is notable for the speed with which it was completed, as well as the number of onscreen killings. Evans, like the greatest of them, uses violence for entertainment purposes, but he never makes it comfortable to watch."The Raid" has significant ramifications since the spectacle does not glorify the carnage. Evans makes their survival strategies more fascinating, but not glamorous. The film examines the essence of movie violence and reaches gloomy conclusions, but it also accepts the genre's appeal.

reviews.review_title: Simple action movie, as simple action movies should be like.
reviews.content: We really need great big fat action-flicks like this one, at least once every couple of years, to remind us that the genre is still very much alive and still has plenty of originality and potential to it as well, as this small budget, Indonesian movie clearly demonstrates.It's really being a very simplistic movie, with both its settings and story but none of this really matters, since basically everything else is done so well.It's a very straightforward action-flick that features plenty of graphic violence in it as well. It's not only an action movie with lots of gunfights and explosions in it, it's also being a true old school material arts flick. And a really good one as well! All of the fights are very well choreographed and filmed and even features some moves that I had never seen before. It's also pretty extreme all, so expect lots of blood flying around and limbs getting crushed. This movie just doesn't ever hold back with any of its violence and it's basically being like a non-stop action spectacle.Perhaps the most surprising thing about this movie remains that it's an Indonesian production. A country that isn't exactly known for its cinema but this movie absolutely looks and feels like a big, multi-million dollar production, with lots of talent and experienced involved, both in front and behind the cameras. Nothing about this movie indicates that it got made with a fairly small budget and with not that many experienced people involved, while in fact this all was actually being the case. A true accomplishment from that perspective but also otherwise, this would had been a great movie to watch, with any sort of budget and language involved.And by saying that his movie does not have a whole lot of story in it, is perhaps not enough credit for this movie. They obviously at least attempted to give the movie some story, even while the entire movie is taking place in the same building. They even managed to give the movie some depth, also with its characters. It's true that its main storyline is a very simple and straightforward one but there is still plenty happening around it with its story and characters. It's really such a professional looking movie, with some great cinematography, editing and just overall style to it. It's brutal and graphic but not in an exploratory kind of way. In a way this movie is being more like a video game than a conventional action-flick perhaps.A great straightforward action-flick, that is a must-see for every lover of the genre, all over the world.8/10 http://bobafett1138.blogspot.com/

I can imagine action filmmakers just sitting around and getting tired of the criticisms about lack of plot. So Gareth Evans decided to give us The Raid. Cops go in to get a crimelord, they end up trapped, lots of fighting and shooting. The film puts fights and choreography before everything else and it is to its credit. Iko Uwais is an action sensation and also knows how to emote using his facial expressions. The fights flow lyrically and Evans always knows where to place the camera. No shaky camera business here. At times the fights did feel too controlled. I kept thinking to my self that I could have a few of these guys in a fight as I would have no qualms with punching their nuts. I know it's a silly nitpick, but the amount of exposed crotches would have lead to shorter fights. Not that I wanted this, but there are no rules when fighting for your life. The violence is well handled and it truly adds to the desperation of the situation, it doesn't try to gross you out but it does want you to feel the shots, stabbings, and punches. Evans also knows to give us a bit of a breather so we can appreciate those action scenes more. There are also a few "how did they do that" moments, which are getting rarer and rarer these days. Yes I wish I had felt more connected to these characters, but for the adrenaline rush it is, it's wonderful.

reviews.review_title: THE RAID is Brutal and Unforgiving in it's Execution
reviews.content: Sometimes, when you want a good solid action movie, you need to steer clear of Hollywood (and their current trend of PG-13, sugar-coated, spastically edited clones) and direct your attention to the other side of the world. In this case, Indonesia. From rising Welsh filmmaker Gareth Evans, THE RAID is a non-stop bloody explosion of martial arts awesomeness. This movie makes no apologies for what it is: a hardcore action film with a massive body count and cringe-inducing kills, with a bit of plot thrown in for flavor. THE RAID is less a movie and more a showcase for talented stuntmen and martial artists and brought together by a man with a passion for the genre. The premise for the movie is simple: Tama is a drug baron is holed up on the fifteenth floor of an apartment building where he oversees his empire, filling the building with junkies and thugs loyal to the cause. He's considered near untouchable, hidden in his fortress with aid from his adviser Andi and a vicious psychopath (referred to as Mad Dogfor a reason). A SWAT unit finds themselves in the precarious position when assigned to bring Tama to justice. We follow rookie officer Rama, one of 20 officers assigned to the mission, as the building is raided and everything turns disastrous when a spotter sounds the alarm. With every thug in the building on the attack and his thoughts returning to his pregnant wife at home, Rama and his surviving fellow officers must survive the assault when they're trapped in the chaos without reinforcements.While, normally, I'd condemn the average mindless Hollywood action schlock, THE RAID gets a special pass for getting right what most American action films get wrong. There is an established plot in the film; it's thin, but it's there. A handful of cops are trapped in an apartment building surrounded by murderous lowlifes and must survive. Once the context is established, THE RAID is all about the action. From about 25 minutes into the film until the very end, this movie is non-stop action, with one sequence transitioning to another with a handful of exposition moments tossed in the middle to keep the story moving. Evans is a longtime fan of the martial arts genre and proves he has a talent for putting action on film. He keeps the camera angles wider so we can witness a lot more of the action, whereas a lot of American action films keep the camera in tight, with fast-moving cuts that often keep the action confusing and disorienting. Evans wants none of that and he shows us every punch, kick, stabbing, etc. The fights are fast and brutal and, more importantly, bloody. None of this bloodless violence we're becoming more and more accustomed to in American action. When people are hit with bullets, knives, machetes, whateverwe see the damage and we feel the impact. It's intense and it makes for some of the coolest fight sequences I've seen in recent years. It's not chockfull of special effects (and those that are utilized are not blatant) and glossed over; it's a handful of talented martial artists and some great choreography.You have to be a bit more open-minded to enjoy THE RAID. The movie is in Indonesian, so I hope you don't mind subtitles or voice dubbing. Another "detriment" to general audiences is a complete lack of recognizable faces in the roles. Evans cast the film with Indonesian martial artists, some of which have never even been in a movie before. Iko Uwais (Rama, the main character) is a Silat specialist (Silat = an Indonesian form of martial arts) who has currently only ever been in two filmsTHE RAID and Evan's smaller first film MERENTAU. You'd never know that he's not a trained actor as he nails his performance in the movie, regardless of his fighting skills. He's sympathetic in his role as Rama with his sense of honor in his job and his unwavering confidence. The same with Yayan Ruhian as Mad Dog, a stuntman and fight choreographer that Evans enlisted as the insane henchman with an insatiable bloodlust. Mad Dog is the coolest character in the movie (despite beingyou knowevil) with a cold- blooded nature and a hint of humor in Ruhian's performance. Overall, THE RAID is a killer action movie that's big on bloody violence and, while short on plot or exposition, accomplishes it's mission of thrilling it's audience with an mind-blowing display of martial arts talent thanks to a passionate director behind the scenes.

reviews.review_title: First class action movie with a raw intensity I've only seen in horror movies
reviews.content: I had heard about THE RAID before it came out but I was unable to find out when it would come out so I struggled to find it. What I didn't know was that the film was Indonesian. But that didn't worry me since I'm partial to foreign films. So I eventually found this film on Blu-Ray (The DVD was sold out.) and saw it and everybody did say this was the best action movie in a long time and its the first time a film with a lot of hype surpassed my expectations by far.This film was fast. intense and almost never lets up. in between the action scenes were the only moments I could catch my breath. The action was just unbelievable. Although I know a few people personally that will definitely complain about it because of the violence but to be honest those people are morons.All in All, its a first class action movie with a raw intensity that I've only ever seen in horror movies THE HILLS HAVE EYES remake and REC and no matter how much people praise it it will still blow you away. Literally.

reviews.review_title: Rarely has the Big Dumb Action Movie Been Bigger, Dumber or More Fun Than This
reviews.content: The Raid: Redemption is the most violent, ridiculously over the top action movie I have ever seen. It could be titled Violence: The Movie with complete accuracy. I don't think I've ever seen so many punches, kicks, and bullets before. And I know I've never seen so many furniture based attacks or men swung around by their legs. This is the kind of film that dares to ask if you can make a movie entirely out of shootouts, explosions, and martial arts, and it answers that question with a resounding yes. You can make that movie, and it will be awesome.Let me start with a little background. I first heard of this movie in a Robert Brockway column entitled "The Most Baffling Subtitles in Foreign Action Movie History" which detailed his experiences watching a poorly translated bootleg of the film. Reading his article, I knew that this movie was the kind of thing I had to see, even without lines like "You must be rest because of both" and "After you see it I sat in s****y pants." I mean where else can you see a guy doing Kung Fu with a florescent tube sticking out of his neck?The brief excuse for a plot involves an elite squad of police launching a raid on a rundown high rise run by one of Jakarta's most notorious crime lords. As they approach the building we get an expository speech about the villain and his chief henchmen, who are made to sound powerful and dangerous beyond all belief. Then we see them; three guys in T-shirts, the leader eating a bowl of ramen. It would seem that his reputation is undeserved. Next we see him finish eating and casually execute half a dozen men, and that impression is immediately dispelled. Then the cops enter the building, and from there it's nonstop action and brutal violence.And I mean brutal. People are stabbed, shot, garroted, strangled, thrown through windows, crushed under filing cabinets and more. At one point a man is hoisted into the air by an axe embedded in his shoulder, slammed to the ground, then axed again. I lost track of the body count less than a minute after the first shot was fired. And there are many, many shots fired. Nor does the Raid stick to that old trope where hundreds of bullets are fired but the heroes don't get hit. Lots of heroes get hit, and most of them die. And the exploding fridge gambit was one of the most original maneuvers used in an action film. John McLane would be proud.If the shootouts and explosions are excellent, the fight scenes are unbelievable. Beyond the standard punch and kick, you have men somersaulting out of arm locks, swinging enemies across the room by their ankles, and delivering spinning kicks to the back of heads. Heroes easily hold off three or more adversaries at a time, turning their attacks against them and impaling them on their allies weapons. This movie doesn't have time for the one at a time attack rule. The blows and parries come incredibly fast, and are only made more impressive by the fact that the moves are real. The low effects budget left no money for wire-fighting techniques, so the actors trained with Indonesian Special Forces instead.If you are at all squeamish or under seventeen, stay away. If you are looking for highbrow fare with any kind of message or moral, keep looking. But if you want nonstop heart pounding action, this is your movie. I can hardly wait for the announced sequel, or the English language remake.

reviews.review_title: Non-stop Action From Start to Finish
reviews.content: When people refer to martial arts films, they are usually thinking about people like Bruce Lee, Jackie Chan, Tony Jaa, Jet Li, Donnie Yen... names that are synonymous with the style of fighting you would expect from them, and the region from which they come from.Enter Iko Uwais (our hero Rama) and Yayan Ruhian (the antagonist Mad Dog) hailing from Indonesia, and masters of their art. This is Pencak Silat, a unique and brutal knife fighting technique developed in the island regions from which they hail. I must admit I had never heard of it before I saw this movie, and most of my martial arts film collection focuses mainly on Japanese and Chinese cinema with a few Thai films here or there, but this one blew me away.The story is about a SWAT team entering a small and dilapidated apartment complex run by one of Jakarta's most brutal drug lords. Every resident is a victim, dealer, or criminal, and every room is rented. They are here under the command of their Lieutenant, in a 20 person unit headed to the top floor to bring down the leader of this loose organization and bring him to justice, or so they think. You are introduced to Rama at the beginning, a man who trains hard, has a wife, a police officer and SWAT unit member with some experience. He has heart, and you get that right from the start, but there is something about him that he hasn't told anyone is his unit, and it's a secret he must keep. The leader of the unit is head strong and sure fire, but things don't go as planned and what follows is a non-stop battle of knives, guns and fists throughout.This movie is a absolute must for actions fans. Even if you don't like foreign cinema, this movie has a lot to teach Hollywood in terms of how you don't need a huge budget to create a fantastic film. Interestingly enough, the movie 'Dredd' (2012) with Karl Urban, came out about a year later. Some critics noticed the similarity in plot between the two films, with 'The Raid-Redemption'(2011) only coming out only a year before. The plot devices are so similar, that the movies could have been interchangeable if not for the characters, time-line, and budget. If you watch those films back to back (I did), you might be surprised at just how these two movies match up in terms of story, events, and theme. Both have cops raiding and apartment, both have drug lords ordering the residents to go after the cops, both films have their character's allegiances tested in similar ways, and both have a floor by floor filming style as they ascend their way to the top level.Although not known for it's movie production and cinematic influence (outside of a few notable documentaries), Indonesia has a lot to be proud of with this film. This one proudly stands right up there at the top. I would certainly love to see more of these actors and their unique style of fighting come out of their homeland. 7/10

Violence has become a mainstream in modern movies, and I am not particularly happy about that. But films like the Raid give me hope.For one the movie as a whole is excellently orchestrated in the method of an SAS strike. It gets in, does the job and gets straight back out again. The film is a crisp 100 minutes long and doesn't waste time dilly dallying around with unnecessary sub plots. Saying that the film is not devoid of substance, the exact amount of back story to flesh the characters out has been included with surgical precision.The main star of the show is the action sequences. They are fast, brutal and visually impressive.I am not a massive fan of action films as I tend to get bored by the incessant beatings the lead role tends to endure. But I found this gripping all the way to the end.

The Raid won't win any awards for originality (indeed, the film is remarkably similar to that of Dredd, which came out the same year); where it does score highly is with its eye-watering, bone-crunching fight scenes which are amongst the most brutal and breath-taking ever committed to celluloid. Once the fists and feet start flying, it's non-stop, blood-drenched action all the way!The film revolves around a team of elite armed policemen who storm a run-down tower block controlled by a gang of violent criminals, but who find themselves in serious trouble when they are ambushed by gunmen and whittled down to a handful of survivors. With this simple set-up, director Gareth Huw Evans (yes, the man behind this incredible Indonesian action flick is Welsh!!!) is free to deliver a martial arts masterpiece of adrenaline-pumping awesomeness, only the occasional ridiculously far-fetched moment (as opposed to just far-fetched) and silly plot development (the introduction of the hero's brother) preventing this from being perfect.

I did watch Merantau a while ago, but I wasn't quite fond of that I have to admit. Not the action scenes in it, but the story/drama wasn't really what I hoped for. Of course as it seems, this was just a training ground (I'll call it that) for making this movie. And "The Raid" is just fantastic! Not that big of a story there of course (actually the title describes what you will see, nothing more, nothing less), but the way the action is shot? Absolutely amazing! A must see.Of course you have to like action movies for that to be true. If you are not that much into them, than don't bother. America took notice and a remake will be on the way (though it won't happen until 2014, so go ahead and watch this before that). I cannot recommend this high enough, something the Empire Magazine does too: It rated the movie with 5 stars (which is a rare rating and is only given to a few movies) ...

reviews.review_title: For those who love martial arts action
reviews.content: It took a little while before it got good. About 25 minutes in I was thinking "I don't care about any of these characters and I am bored." But I stuck it out and I am glad that I did. After the first half an hour it got really good.The fight scenes are gritty and good. There was only a few spots where I thought that something was unrealistic.All of the scenes regarding the storyline were the weakest scenes in the movie. The plot itself was a little weak, but it doesn't really matter in this case because there is a lot of kick ass action to make up for it.The fight choreography was good and the ending was satisfying. I don't need to say much more than that really.

reviews.review_title: Action does not get better than this
reviews.content: A drug lord lives in a fortified apartment block. An elite squad of police infiltrate the building to arrest him. It does not go the way they wanted it to. That's the plot. There are a few more bells and whistles, including our main hero cop finding an unlikely ally in the building, but essentially this film is non-stop action. Extremely brutal and incredibly intricately staged incredible action. By distilling the crucial ingredients to their basic essence and working like hell to pull of some incredible fight choreography and insane stunt work, Gareth Evans has made the best action film of the last 20 years.

reviews.review_title: "The Expendables" and "Ong Bak" in a blender!!!
reviews.content: Here's The Lowedown on "The Raid: Redemption" (An Action/Martial Arts DVD review)...LOVED IT!! Become a fan of The Lowedown on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/pages/The-Lowedown/386583633764 What's it about? In the Jakarta slums, a derelict apartment building has become a no-go area - even the police are unwilling to enter. It has become a safe-house for the most dangerous killers and gangsters. A SWAT team infiltrate the building, under the cover of darkness, to remove its owner - a notorious drug lord named Tama.What did I think? This was one of the best pure action movies I have seen in a long time. The fight scenes were so impressive (armed and unarmed), that it has you gripped from start to finish. If you take "Ong Bak" and "The Expendables" then put them in a blender...you get "The Raid: Redemption". Stick this one in your player ASAP.

reviews.review_title: a fun, inventive, brutal, over the top, and action-packed movie experience!!
reviews.content: The Raid: Redemption follows the story of a group of SWAT officers who infiltrate a run-down tenement in order to take down a criminal gang leader. They soon become trapped and pursued by an army of criminals. I will not hesitate in saying that this is one of the most action packed movies I have ever seen! Within the first ten minutes, they are in the building and the carnage begins and does not stop until the end.The fight scenes are palpable and graphic; you can clearly see what is happening and everything is right in your face (I mean this in the best possible way). This is a breath of fresh air for action-fans such as myself because many action movies now a days use shaky and quick-cut camera-work so they do not actually have to show what is happening. Others use excessive amounts of CGI so everything seems fake. This movie on the other hand makes everything that happens easy to see; you actually see people punching, kicking, shooting, stabbing, slicing, and killing each other. Nothing is left to the imagination. The movie is also very suspenseful, especially in the first act when the SWAT team first gets ambushed and are running around doing everything they can to survive and save every last man. Everything from that point on is, as Rotten Tomatoes puts it, all thrills and no frills. The whole movie feels almost like a video-game, just action, fighting, shooting, survival, suspense, and lots and LOTS of action! The movie does a great job of being creative with the fight scenes and being as brutal and intense as possible. I found myself cringing and going "OOOHH!! That's gotta hurt!" at so many times throughout the movie. I suppose the main problem I have with The Raid: Redemption is the lack of character development. You know very little about any of the characters and it makes it extremely difficult to have any sympathy for them. For a movie as action-packed as this, it would not have killed anyone if they added 5-10 minutes of character development in the beginning. In conclusion, The Raid: Redemption is an amazing action movie with some of the best fight scenes ever put to film. If you are looking for interesting characters and a deeper meaning, you will not find it here, but you will find a great amount of entertainment much better then 90% of the action movies in recent years.

reviews.review_title: You haven't seen wall-to-wall action like this
reviews.content: The foreign indie flick, The Raid, is an amazing work of art. It doesn't have any noteworthy plot or acting, but it is remarkable for its action and the tense and at-times unpredictable and creative scenes. I think The Raid is one of the best action films ever made.The choreography and cinematography of the fight scenes are amazing. Often, many action films have some errors/flaws or the fights seem fake but I didn't notice any major flaws with the scenes here. The director and the stunt coordinator, along with the actors, have done a very good job making everything seem so real.If you are into martial arts films, or if you have never seen a really good one, you should check out this film.You don't know what wall-to-wall action is until you see this film!
If you like violent movies, a lot of bloods, fighting scenes that look real, you will agree with me that this is the best action martial art movie ever.

reviews.review_title: You may wind up with blood on your shirt....
reviews.content: Tension. Tension. Shootout. Tension. Shootout. More Tension. Fight. Fight. Fight. Fight. This is The Raid in a nutshell. This film is a rock em' sock em' absolutely brutal beatdown of an action film that takes no prisoners, pulls no punches, and is not afraid of making you cringe. Plot be damned, because it's all about the video game-like action that sprinkles itself in the 90+ minutes of pure Indonesian mayhem.For those that still want to know what it's about, The Raid starts off with our male lead leaving his pregnant wife to do a mission. The mission is simple: raid a creepy abandoned building and arrest the guy responsible for running all the illegal nonsense. What follows are plot twists, plot turns, a few surprises, plenty of clichés, and enough action to cover two summer seasons. Not kidding in the least bit, action junkies will get their fix and some with this flick.The Raid's biggest strengths can be contributed to the direction and cinematography. This film lacks lighting; it lacks a polished look, and avoids the wide shot like the dickens--giving it a very gritty feel. Close-ups are abundant when building tension, when the stakes are raised, and especially when the fights are delivered. Containing some of the best-directed martial arts since Jackie Chan himself, the fights are extremely well-choreographed, tightly edited, and are so intense that during my viewing, half the audience walked out. This is no PG-13 fight flick, you'll see nasty body blow after blow, and see more knives than a butcher, and more fatalities than every Mortal Kombat game combined. The death and dismembered count is nice and high.For the nitpicky, the plot is definitely clichéd and definitely predictable. For the nitpicky, the acting is honestly not the best, and neither is the writing. But nobody is walking into this movie to focus on any type of story. You are entering this movie with three things in mind: action, carnage, and martial arts.And you will have plenty of all three.And perhaps way more than you can handle.

Now I saw this movie for one reason, and one reason only, it was hyped up beyond belief. I think the only two other movies that have come out this year that have been more hyped up are "The Hunger Games," and "The Cabin in the Woods." I really had no idea what this film was about going into it, I basically read a one sentence sympnosis of it. So, was the movie as good as everyone is making it out to be? Kinda.OK, I will say that for the most part, I really enjoyed this movie. The acting is great, I of course saw this with subtitles, so I got the actual actors and not someone dubbing over it. The fight scenes are very, very well choreographed. That's the main fun of the movie is the fighting and the violence. There is a lot of violence in this movie, and there are sometimes where it got hard to watch. I cringed several times. The villains are great, I just clenched my fists, waiting for them to die. And the plot was, really well done, I had a little trouble trying to keep up at times.But that is also one of the movies main problems, there were times where I just went "huh." That might not be a bad thing, but it hurt my enjoyment of the film. Also I wasn't a big fan of the characters, they aren't bad, but there are just too many of them and I really only gave a crap about two of them. And some characters do the stupidest things. There was a point when one of the villains has someone tied up. Aother good guy comes in, and he lets the other guy go so he can fight them both. And it's not like he has a weapon, he just decides to go 2 on 1.Other than that, I didn't have many problems with this film. It isn't too long, so it's worth seeing unless you aren't a fan of violent films.7.5/10

I saw the trailer for this Indonesian film at the time of its release and it looked really cool and exciting, and I was really lucky to be able to see it before it was available to most of the public, I just hoped it would live up to the good rating the critics gave it. Basically a derelict apartment building, fifteen stories high, in the heart of the slums, serves as a safe house for some of the most dangerous criminals in Jakarta, it is considered impregnable and untouchable by rivals of the crime lord Tama Riyadi (Ray Sahetapy) and even the police, but an elite SWAT team have been tasked with storming the block and taking the mobster down. Expectant father and rookie cop Rama (Iko Uwais) is part of the twenty man team raiding the building, with Sergeant Jaka (Joe Taslim) leading and Lieutenant Wahyu (Pierre Gruno) guiding them, and to get inside they have one of the local residents, who is returning with medicine for his sick wife, help them out, and other residents along the way are silenced and tied up to stop detection. It is when the team reach the sixth floor however that a young lookout spots them and raises the alarm to the criminals that the police are inside, before he is shot and killed, and Tama calls for reinforcements, while two snipers take the two officers outside on the ground floor trapping the team inside, and slowly of the SWAT team members are killed in the growing chaos. Tama shuts down the power inside the building so that they cannot go any further than the sixth floor, and he alerts all other residents and criminals inside that will be rewarded becoming permanent residents if they kill the intruders. Sergeant Jaka learns that the mission was not authorised by the department, so there is no one that knows they are raiding the building or that will be coming to help them, and eventually after lengthy battle and lots of gunfire only six members of the team remain. Sergeant Jaka, Lieutenant Wahyu, Bowo (Tegar Satrya), Dagu (It Eka 'Piranha' Rahmadia) and Rama have survived the ambush, but are low on ammunition and being hunted by the various criminals, there is a point when Rama and Bowo manage to get some help from the man with his sick wife hiding in a secret passage behind a wall, they are lucky to survive gang heavies searching for them. Rama gets kidnapped by Tama's right hand man Andi (Donny Alamsyah), while the group with Jaka are caught by Tama's ruthless henchman Mad Dog (Yayan Ruhian), Wahyu manages to escape, and Dagu is ordered to follow him. Mad Dog and Jaka go against each other, but they decide to drop their weapons and fight with their martial arts skills, Jaka is defeated and killed, while in Andi's apartment he reveals that Tama is his alienated brother, and he returns to Tama with Mad Dog dragging the body of Jaka, but the lead criminal saw Andi's betrayal with Rama on CCTV and stabs him in the hand. Tama is located on the fifteenth floor in a narcotics lab setting, and Rama, Wahyu and Dagu regroup to go and stop Mad Dog from beating up Andi, Rama and Andi kill Mad Dog, while Wahyu and Dagu go to get Tama. Eventually after the fighting and going up the stairs the police team members catch up to Tama, after Dagu was shot dead by Wahyu, but he goes against his original instinct and kills Tama with a shot in the head, but he cannot kill himself as well when he runs out of ammo, and in the end Rama, Bowo walk out of the apartment building with Andi and the captured Wahyu, but Andi returns to the building as the officers walk away. Also starring Verdi Solaiman as Budi, Ananda George as Ari and Iang Darmawan as Gofar. Most of the cast members make their characters memorable enough, especially the criminal mastermind protected by all his thugs inside the building, I will admit I did get a little confused with the plot towards the middle, but overall the story is enough to get, a raid in a building full of criminals armed to the teeth, obviously it is made the most exciting by the rapid gunfire, some small explosions, the martial arts fight sequences and the high violence content, it is indeed an exciting and inventive action crime thriller film. Very good!

reviews.review_title: High Flying Martial Arts Makes an Impression
reviews.content: You want action? You got it. Explosive gun fighting for the first third of the movie, then electric hand to hand combat takes over. No shortage of high energy action. These guys fight for ten minutes straight and are barely breathing through their mouth by the end of it, clearly they had their coffee that morning.There's not too much plot wise. The police force, specifically the higher ups are obviously in many ways corrupt, and the featured SWAT team are essentially lambs to the slaughter... Enter Rama (Iko Uwais). Iko and other cast members get to show off their mad Martial Arts skills, which sets this apart from many other standard action flicks. Most likely the Hollywood introduction of the Indonesian Martial Art 'Pencak Silat', which has become prevalent in modern action movies such as the 'John Wick' series, and most recently 'Extraction'.I found it somewhat amusing that when the SWAT team either lost their guns or ran out of ammo, conveniently the bad guys did too. From thereon they all resorted to only machetes or hand to hand. And man, these guys can take incredible non stop beatings, and still look pretty good afterwards.In any case, quality effects and stunts make this very entertaining for any action junkie.

I have to say that this film was something else. Iko Uwais, (Rama) a S.W.A.T. member of twenty men who are brought in to take down a brutal mobster king pin Tama (Ray Sahetapy). Through their routine of infiltration a young boy they stumble upon was the catalyst to starting the most intense fighting using weapons or guns at their disposal. Now both Rama and his partners must find a way out before becoming the next casualty. Yet in the hideout with Tama, is a rogue wolf brother of Rama's who becomes the next one hunted. Through the entire building each squad member must face an opponent, in small or large groups. I must confess, that although I do not like Mui Tai boxing, it does show a great deal of intricate moves which one could become dizzy with. It reminds me of Tony Jaa in Ong Bak. Fantastic fight scenes, between the brothers and Mad Dog (Yayan Ruhian). As for the story itself, it was slightly offbeat with the guess of who is in with the kingpin kind of thing. Most of the clues lead to their lieutenant who devised the raid in the first place. This told me it was the lieutenant in the first hour when Rama heard how no back up was coming to save them. However, moving around the building for the whole movie was a nice trick. You were never bored, action through out, but the characters needed to pick up a few more emotional sequences to make it more intense with the story. But -- to be fair, these days Indonesian films have become quite the trend now with new stories, new fights, and new ways to wow the crowd. Excellent acting from Iko Uwais. Much like Tony Jaa, they can fit any role.

Cult Cuts Volume 5#2/4: The Raid: Redemption (2011)(9/10):Well I think I found a new favourite for the year of 2011.This is, quite simply put, one of the best action films ever made. The Raid is an Indonesian action film that advertises itself with the tagline of "1 Minute of Romance. 99 Minutes of Non-Stop Carnage", and it delivers on that promise.It's a film that I wish I had seen all in one go as it feels like that would very much have helped how I feel about it because it's an adrenaline rush that,if you take too long of a break from,loses its effect and it's level of fluidity.The film is in a foreign language and there are subtitles, but it's more just to provide some kind of context as to why this is all happening, it's not strong in the story or dialogue department, it's all in the action.It's an action film that places practically all emphasis on the action,as an action film should provided being that the action is legitimately good and not dumb. This film isn't dumb, it delivers a true rush with many well choreographed fight scenes,tight pacing,gory effects and just enough story to give everything you're seeing purpose.It's a simple film,does one thing well, but what it does well, it excels in.Highly recommend, even if you're not into subtitles, it's just that great of an action film to pass up on.

reviews.review_title: Disappointment Is Certainly Not An Option Here
reviews.content: One of the most incredible, exhilarating & heart-pounding action films to come out in a long time, The Raid (also known as The Raid: Redemption) is possibly the purest form of action extravaganza that has ever graced the film canvas which, apart from bringing a smile on every action film lover with its maddening depiction of blood, violence & insane fight sequences, also marks a significant breakthrough for the so-far-invisible Indonesian film industry to come into the attention of world cinema audience.Although by no means it is a perfect film, but when it comes to pure adrenaline rush, thrilling factor & entertainment value, action films don't get anymore exciting, inventive or satisfying than this high-octane, full-throttled & top-gear action spectacle. The plot concerns a raid operation taking place in a 15 storey apartment building which houses a ruthless crime lord and tells the story of a rookie officer amongst them. When their presence is known in the building, the cops are left with no choice but to do anything it takes to make out of the dreaded place in a single piece.To be honest, there isn't much to bother with the story of The Raid because it only serves as a reasonable justification to all the endless carnage that surrounds this film. Written, edited & directed by Gareth Evans, who surely knows what great action is all about, the film boasts some amazing fight sequences which are amazingly well captured. Cinematography presents a bleak picture that perfectly fits with the inhospitable look of the building while the entire story is explosively paced & tightly edited for maximum entertainment.Coming to the performances, there isn't anything to praise but the cast leaves nothing major to complain about too. Iko Uwais plays Rama; the rookie cop around whom the story revolves & does a neat enough job with his role. Yayan Ruhian impresses the most as Mad Dog & is a show- stealer in every single scene. Rest are good in their given roles too but it's Uwais & Ruhian who put up some of the most amazing action stunts ever filmed on camera. The soundtrack also contributes greatly in fuelling the intensity of the film with its adrenaline boosting tracks.Every cinema lover has few movies which they absolutely adore no matter how many noticeable flaws, loopholes or inconsistencies it may have for it's their unique cinematic experience which makes them exclusively special. The Raid fits into that category of films. It has a decent story & typical plot developments, but the sheer jaw-dropping experience it provides with its insane action is something that even many technically perfect films fail to emulate.On an overall scale, with its remarkable use of guns, machetes & martial arts during its fight sequences, The Raid takes action in cinema to a whole new level of awesomeness & amazement and is a violent ride of intense & insane action that guarantees a breathtaking experience for action film lovers. Therefore, in case you are one, then don't even dare to miss this action masterpiece because disappointment is certainly not an option here.

reviews.review_title: Probably the craziest movie I've ever seen. Wickedly satisfying.
reviews.content: When I finished watching this movie... I was left speechless. Usually, I would probably dislike mindless action films... the only notable exceptions being Transformers and Ninja Assassin, both guilty pleasures in their own right.The Raid came off as the most insane movie I've ever seen. Gareth Evans really had the guts to pull it off: giving us a clichéd protagonist with a mediocre motivation and a weak, nonsensical plot, and instead, throws at us 99 solid minutes of mindless skull-bashing action and brain-numbing violence, inviting us to step into one adrenaline-maxed out scenario after another, the intensity of the fights escalating as the movie progresses, making all of the Hong Kong action films I grew up watching seem like child's play.The film does have its rare calm moments in between brawls, but they are all too short to make an impression. When it does cool down... you're biting your nails, wondering what vicious and imaginative way would the director execute another fight scene or kill more people off. And when it arrives, the sequences would leave any viewer attempting to catch their breath... but the film just leaves no room for that.Mindless action aside, the cinematography and editing were awesome, not what was I expecting from a movie that cost 1.1 million dollars to make, contributing to the intensity of the film. The gritty and dark photography cranks up the tension to the max, making it one of the best films that would get your heart racing by the second minute, a wondrous experience for action fanatics.Forget the solid acting, the unbelievable situations of the film (Where the hell in Jakarta can you find a flat populated entirely by ridiculously psychotic or mentally sick criminals who knows how to put up a good fight whenever confronted?), the terrible and recycled writing. Leave your brain at the doorstep and watch it, immense yourself. I highly recommend this to any action fan.

reviews.review_title: A must-see for all action junkies, this is the quintessential martial-arts movie, packed wall-to-wall with no-holds-barred thrills and exhilarating real-life stunts
reviews.content: Just when the Asian martial-arts genre had lost one of its brightest young stars Tony Jaa to mysticism, along comes Indonesian actor Iko Uwais to give it a renewed kick of life- and boy let's just say that it is not simply a kick, but more accurately a lightning jolt. Fans of the genre shouldn't be all too surprised at the hype surrounding 'The Raid: Redemption', the second collaboration between Iko and Welsh-born director Gareth Evans- their first Merantau' already offered a peek at what the 31-year-old 'silat' practitioner was capable of.Learning from the lessons of their earlier film, Gareth has pared down the elements of plot, character, dialogue and perhaps most importantly culture specificity to deliver a quintessential action film that riffs on Hollywood classics like 'Die Hard' and 'Assault on Precinct 13'. So the premise is kept simple but yet efficient- an elite special forces team is ordered to raid a grimy tenement building that has long been the stronghold of a powerful drug kingpin Tama (Ray Sahetapy).Uwais' character Rama is one of the police officers sent into the suicide mission, introduced with a tersely told prologue that sees him kissing his pregnant wife goodbye and telling his father that he will 'bring home' his presumably lost brother. Gareth, who also wrote the screenplay, uses the former insofar as motivation for Rama to keep fighting and reserves the latter for a somewhat unexpected plot twist that gives the film more depth than you would expect.Otherwise, he keeps his focus on the setup for the action sequences which are unequivocally the purpose of the entire movie. Right from the start, we are left in anticipation for that climactic fight between Rama and Tama's two henchmen Andi (Doni Alamsyah) and Mad Dog (Yayan Ruhian), the latter of whom is described by the team leader (former Indonesian judo champion Joe Taslim) as 'a maniac of feet and fists that would tear down walls for his boss'. That doesn't mean however that Gareth, who co- choreographed the action with Yayan and Iko himself, takes it easy in the meantime.Rather, he unleashes all the bullets at his disposal within the first half-hour, as the team finds themselves up and against every lowlife tenant in the building, promised free rent by Tama if they can rid the building of its recent 'cockroach infestation'. What's worse, the building is rigged with cameras at every corner and on every floor which Tama views from the safety of his control room right up on the fifteenth storey- and suffice to say it isn't long before the whole team is whittled down to just Rama, his team leader and their corrupt boss Lt. Wahyu (Pierre Gruno).No matter really- simplicity is still ultimately the beauty of this no- holds-barred action movie so the faster we get to the good guys that matter the better. To up the ante, our heroes are clearly outnumbered as they are set upon floor by floor by thugs wielding knives, guns and machetes. Even though these earlier fights are just appetisers for the main showdown, it is evident that no lack of effort has been made to ensure that each is gripping to the bone.Amidst snapped necks, smashed skulls and slit throats, the singular thing that impresses is the thrilling efficiency by which Iko dispatches his opponents. There is nothing too elaborate that the killings appear contrived; rather, brutal as they may be, Iko keeps them realistic and most of all inventive, coming up with new ways each time round to ensure that the brawls are always never less than captivating. Kudos to Iko for both his choreography and execution, both of which combine to emphasise the artistic aspect in the martial-arts form on display.In contrast to Iko's Rama, there is something elementally frightening about Yahan's Mad Dog, who in an extended sequence sure to make the squeamish wince, uses his plain fisticuffs to beat one of the police officers to his death instead of ending it quickly with his pistol. "This is what I do," he says, holding up his hands- so formidable is he that when Rama eventually takes him on, it becomes a two-against-one battle with the odds in the latter's favour.That finale, taking place inside the confines of an iron-walled room, is one of the most exhilarating and exhausting fight scenes ever captured on film, capped with a satisfyingly violent finish that had the audience at this reviewer's screening clapping their hands in glee. And the best part about it is that you get to see every move in the clarity it deserves, both lensers- Matt Flannery and Dimas Imam Subhono- constantly offering fresh new angles to the action and vehemently eschewing the kind of shaky-cam or quick editing Hollywood is too fond of employing nowadays.Complemented with a pulsating score by Joseph Trapanese and Linkin Park's Mike Shinoda, there is no doubt this exceptional film deserves all the positive buzz that has come its way since premiering to raves at the Toronto International Film Festival. It is relentlessly breathtaking every step of the way, building tension and excitement minute by minute until it unleashes its ultimate salvo guaranteed to leave you cheering. Under the assured hands of director Gareth Evans, who despite his young age has mastered a skillful grasp on the action genre, 'The Raid: Redemption' is also sure to be a star-making vehicle for Iko- and if you can't quite figure out why there is the word 'redemption' in its title, then take it simply for the fact that it has brought due recognition to the dazzling partnership between Iko and Gareth after the under- appreciated 'Merantau'.www.moviexclusive.com

Alright, the action isn't quite non-stop, but it is pretty close. That being said they have actually managed to get a bit of a story thrown in, a relatively solid story at that.The premise is that a SWAT team, mostly full of rookies, is sent in to an apartment building to extract a crime lord. They have to deal with the fact that most of the tenants of the building are criminals, there are lookouts on every floor and a video surveillance system. It also becomes clear rather quickly that the lieutenant leading the assault isn't on the up and up.The first portion of the movie starts with the SWAT team doing what they do best. Methodically and quietly clearing the building as they move ever upward. Then things fall apart and they are in an extended gun battle.The action in the movie isn't limited to gun fights. There is a scene that reminded me of the hallway scene in Old Boy, but with knives, tonfa (police baton) and one cop marching through dozens of bad guys. There is also time for a couple of brutal hand-to-hand fights.The plot I alluded to earlier is hard to outline without spoiling the movie. It is clear that ulterior motives abound, most obviously in the lieutenant who arranges the raid. But as the movie unfolds, it becomes clear that there is more going on. I'm not saying the plot would win any Oscars, but I was pleasantly surprised at how well it played out.

I am usually not into action films unless they are really good.
This one is totally unique and is now one my #1 action favorite. 
This movie is like nothing made before. And is so awesome. Go see it.

reviews.review_title: One of the best martial art movies out there
reviews.content: The plot of the 2011 movie The Raid: Redemption is in a way, similar to the 2012 movie Dredd. In both cases, police officers are trapped in a residential high rise, having to battle through waves of cold blooded criminals who are eager to end the heroes' lives. But that is where the similarity ends. In The Raid, the criminals come in swarms. The actors are also quite adept at martial arts, so the jarring 1 second and half second cuts of action seen in some other action movies aren't used here. The fight coordinator also gets a chance to prove their talent, making the fights seem both overwhelming but also believable. Bad guys lining up one by one is not a trope used here.At the same time though, this is also a police drama. While all scenes take place within and outside of this one building after the first minutes, the movie introduces conflicts and questions about potential alliances and corruption coming from the department itself.Although I've seen the movie several times now in its original Taiwanese, I did watch a few minutes of a few scenes with the English dubbing, and it seemed to be well done also. The voice actors seemed like a good fit for the characters they were playing, and both the dialog and the timing seemed rather close to the English translation. I lack the ability to follow French, so the level of that audio track isn't something that I can judge.The only detail which fans of this type of movie might object to though, is the violence. While it is by no means gratuitous, and you don't see any of the excessive measures that some filmmakers sometimes go for, there are a few scenes which would be clearly cut if the movie were ever shown on network TV. One example would be one of the many people trying to kill a police officer, getting thrown out a window, and falling a few stories so that a railing bends their back unnaturally far backwards. The editing is rather clever so that you see this person from their attack straight through to their fall and their literal back-breaking landing. There are only a handful of scenes like this which would go beyond network prime time programming, but if such scenes would kill your day, you might want to avoid this movie. But again, what it shows isn't beyond what one might see under such circumstances, nor is it the point of the movie.In short, this is a good film for anybody who likes a great martial arts movie or a good police story. Although the main actors aren't quite as talented as Bruce Lee in his technique or as Jackie Chan in his death defying stunt work, the level of skill is beyond what you'd see from most of the main characters of a Marvel or DC movie. In short, this movie is worthy of Sony's "Classics" label.

reviews.review_title: The Raid is Insane-- in a good way
reviews.content: In "The Raid: Redemption" the awesome fight scene has brothers Rama (Iko Uwais) and Andi (Donny Alamsyah) trading punches, kicks, and locks with Mad Dog (badass Yayan Ruhian). The fight literally lasts 10 minutes. Rama and Andi are attacking Mad Dog simultaneously—none of this one at a time stuff. Director and writer Gareth Evans also shoots full body action sequences-- no quick cut edits of torso moves. Uwais is a master of Silat, Indonesian martial art, and really kicks some ass up to this point. But Mad Dog is unstoppable—a master perhaps jacked up on meth. The fight scene is insane, one of the best in movies ever. "The Raid" is awesome. As my bud Robert, a film director, pointed out that the production values are weak, and the narrative is thin. However, he also said that you see "The Raid" for the amazing martial arts.Set in Jakarta, Uwais plays Rama, who is a SWAT member and expectant father. Uwais is good-looking, charismatic, and deathly calm. His SWAT team raids the tower safe house of drug lord Tama (over the top evil Ray Sahetapy), lead by Lt. Jaka (earnest Joe Taslim). Tama commands from the top floor of the tower, and has his henchmen wreak havoc on those below. Rama has another more personal mission: He must rescue the soul of his prodigal brother Andi (strong and smart Donny Alamsyah). The story has been done before—reminiscent of Bruce Lee's "Game of Death". Once the automatic weapons play out, the movie goes wild—in a good way. The sword fighting is also amazing.I was not familiar with the Indonesian martial art Silat. Silat is like Muay Thai, close in elbows and knees. Silat also uses kung fu round kicks and blows. Uwais and Ruhian throw nice boxing hooks. There are also cool locks, chokes, and throws. Silat is beautiful and brutal.See "The Raid" for the electrifying martial arts action. The acting is solid and the story is derivative. The showcase fight scene with the brothers taking on Mad Dog is spectacular. I wonder how many times Evans had to film the scene. It was definitely worth it.

reviews.review_title: Made to make you scream and groan, not to make you think or weep..
reviews.content: Your stomach might hurl, your eyes might wince at watching the violence in this film, but you might not wanna watch any other action films ever again! Because in terms of action films, this one will make Die Hard, Transporter and Lethal Weapon movies like a 12 year old girl in schoolgirl uniform. Everything you know in action films, this film is four to six storeys higher. I even think Mad Dog, the second main villain in this film, can kick Darth Vader's butt to Timbuktu.. Yes its that good. Apparently I keep hearing people complaining this movie lacks of plot and acting. This is a martial art film, people! Of course you cant compare this with Cabin In The Woods or Titanic 3D.. It's like your'e expecting a ride in a Boeing airline, from a Lamborghini.What kind of ride this film was, people will get shot in the head at point blank, people get stabbed not only once but multiple times, people get thrown of a balcony only to be a landing mat, etc. etc in ways you never have imagine before.So please, don't bring your kids to this movie, or your spouses who happens to enjoy Jennifer Aniston's movie. And you have to leave your moral and education values at the Theater door. Because this film is made for one purpose only.. Bloodshed FUN!

reviews.review_title: Think Action, think Martial Arts, think Hong Kong? Think again, think Indonesia!
reviews.content: Visually stunning martial arts fights, mainly modern Pencak Silat, paired with epic action-shootouts entraps the viewer in to the world of this action movie. Think Action, think Martial Arts, think Hong Kong? Think again, think Indonesia! The story line plays with the ancient theme of the two unequal brothers who lost sight of each other, good cop vs. bad cop and choosing ones own destiny, not because the movie character likes it but because the character has developed a fixed skill set and excels with this skill set in his world. Both worlds, morally good vs morally questionable, are combined in this movie and the viewers is left with an explanation why the character act the way the act and why they have chosen their path of life. This movie got a good story- line, is well acted with clearly defined and likable characters AND non-stop rushing adrenaline fights. It is this combination that makes me giving this movie the vote: 9 of 10.
The review title says it all: turn your brain off and watch the action unfold. That's pretty much all you need if you like heavy action and martial arts.

To be honest I was surprised by the quality of this movie, but it happens to be one of the best martial arts films within the past decade. The story wasn't gonna blow your socks off but it was interesting and entertaining. Most of the characters feel real and the movie succeeds in getting you involved in the plot. But the real highlight of this movie is the action and fight scenes. Just stunning really. The choreography and cinematography was on point. They really put their hearts and souls in this movie and it shows.

reviews.review_title: The Most Refined Action Sequence in Cinematic History
reviews.content: Kung fu needs a new publicist.Somewhere along the way, martial arts acquired a bad reputation.Perhaps Keanu's been over-quoted.Regardless, a number of great movies from the past few decades feature hand-to-hand combat: The Matrices, Shanghai Noon, the Rush Hours, Rumble in the Bronx.(Sidebar: Top two films involving a woodchipper: Rumble in the B and Fargo.)Now, hesitation's healthy when a martial art is all a motion picture offers.The Raid: Redemption is a lot more than just kung fu.If ever I review a flick that's entirely male-oriented, it's The Raid.It's often compared to another movie released around the same time, because both flicks portray an assault on a crime-ridden high-rise.Dredd, however, isn't good.Lena Headey as the cruel antagonist, and SLO-MO (the reality altering drug) are the only redeeming aspects in that overrated reboot. Everybody that played GoldenEye 007 on N64 is well-aware of proximity mines, smoke grenades and the like.On the contrary, The Raid is fantastic.The fellow who owns the criminal complex being raid redeemed has an interrogation room with a chain restraining system. It's a chamber specifically suited towards information extraction via shackled prisoners.Speaking without hyperbole, Raid: Red contains the single greatest action sequence in cinematic history.Gareth Evans deserves a standing ovation for the fire axe scene.The tension is multi-layered as the characters realistically adapt to an evolving conflict. There are varied threats and the individual movement through the scenery (plus the interplay with props/weaponry) is magnificent.It's a delicate waltz, my Friends.A riveting score overlays elaborate choreography, creative stunts and sharp camera-work.The Raid is originally an Indonesian film and Sony Pictures tasked Mike Shinoda (of Linkin Park and Fort Minor) with creating a new score for the U.S. market. The Shinoda scored version made its U.S. debut at Sundance 2012.The fire axe is just one of many great scenes though. Rent it and see for yourself.The stakes are high. The plot is smart and dark.Neither slasher nor 'torture porn.'It's as good as action gets.Somebody at the festival must have noticed the issue with the subtitles, right?Whoever translated the closed captioning did very poor work. One of the main barriers between non-viewers is the necessary reading, so naturally a minimalist approach would seem appropriate.There were subtitles for grunts, music notes to indicate the swell of Shinoda's composition (which goes against the very nature of a film score), footsteps and other sound effects. This would make sense if America were a deaf culture.One subtitle in particular, "Okay (English)," appears toward the middle of the film. This is more than a distraction. It's especially problematic because it instigates needless confusion.Why the distributors haven't fixed the closed captions (especially now the sequel's been released) is beyond me.But behold; I let it go. You will too.If you're a lady who loved The Raid, please set me straight; your comments are welcome!Gentlemen – go nuts.

reviews.review_title: The most satisfying action film in years!
reviews.content: After hearing so much about The Raid, I knew I had to see it. I am a sucker for foreign action flicks, particularly Asian action, and The Raid is one of the best I've seen in a long, long time. My usual complaints about action films generally stem from a lack of action to satisfy and a lack of diversity in the action presented. Not here. The Raid is so filled with action and is creative enough with it, that any action buff will be satisfied with what is presented.The Raid is simple enough: a special forces team is sent into a derelict apartment housing filled with criminal dwellers. However, the mission goes wrong and it's a fight for survival as the remaining team fights through the floors to reach the top and take out their main target. There is little downtime in this film. With a few expositionary scenes, the majority of the film is dedicated to ass kicking. And ass kicking it does plenty of. Everything an action junkie could want is here. From gun fights to one on one combat to two on one combat, there is no shortage of adrenaline here. And the action is all brutal, with no wire-fu or special effects seen here. It's all bone-crunching, throat slicing, body beating realism.Thankfully the fights are not only varied, with few of them seeming repetitive or boring, and they are all shown with great precision. There is very little incoherence here or shaky cam, one of the many faults that seem to plague modern action films. The Raid is presented with great skill. It's in part due to the presentation and skill in filmmaking that this is such an accomplished action film. This includes the acting, which is adequate for the film. Our main hero, Rama, played by the very competent Iko Uwais, comes across as an every man, similar to Tony Jaa or Jackie Chan. We see that he is more a skilled man simply trying to stay alive than a super soldier or one man army. This increases the tension in many scenes, as we genuinely feel that these characters, each of the good guys, are in real danger. And there are enough tension filled scenes to put you on the edge of your seat.With bone crunching, brutal, and bloody combat, The Raid is the best action film in years. It's a damn shame this isn't in more theaters, because it really does deserve to be seen by anyone who likes action films. It's many awesome moments will have you salivating for more, and by the time the film is over, you'll be hungry for more.

Many people had told me this film is absolutely awesome, and usually I am skeptical of such hype. However having seen the film I was very entertained and very impressed.The story is nothing amazing but does give context as to why events are occurring. What we become mostly interested in is the survival of certain characters. And this is heightened by the solid execution of the action scenes which are just so good. At the end of each fight I was completely in awe of the precision, brutality and seeming realism depicted. As expected the most impressive fight is the last and it will not disappoint; in fact I was cheering with glee the whole time.If you love martial arts and love action films you will be absolutely thrilled.

reviews.review_title: Double bill - The Raid and The Raid 2
reviews.content: Double bill time, Welsh filmmaker Gareth Evans has made a big splash with his action one-two punch which puts the Indonesian martial art "Pencak Silat" on a bigger map. Swimming against the tide of an inexorably digitized world, since the noughties, action movies have been experiencing a somewhat fundamentalistic revolution ushered in by ONG-BAK: THE THAI WARRIOR (2003), where a more tactile, point-blank and lethal combat style greatly relying on the performers' physical prowess sounding the death knell for a plethora of CGI-heavy schlock, and Gareth Evans takes the revolution further down that road, at any time of the day, it is more than welcomingBlanketed in its slate blue hue, THE RAID: REDEMPTION has a setting like a single-location entrapment horror flick, a catastrophic heavy blow incurs to a team of elite squad when they raid inside a tenement tower block owned by the crime lord Tama Riyado (Sahetapy) in Jakarta's slums, it turns out to be a set-up as a corollary of corruption among police top-brass. Assailed by not zombies but practically zombie-looking inhabitants (bedraggled drug addicts mostly) and a cohort of Tama's henchmen, they might find some painful irony (if they are still breathing) from recollecting the paradoxical pep talk of Sergeant Jaka (Taslim), who is leading the raid, paraphrasing here: it is a highly dangerous mission, but I don't want to see any of those seats empty when we return. The one who is bestowed with a protagonist nimbus is Rama (Uwais), a tyro in the forces and has an ax to grind in the game, when all the ammo is expended, his killer martial art skill starts to tip the scale in the bloodshed. Since its no-account story-line seldom fluctuates with plot development (barring a fraternal reunion), and although many tropes of suspense routinely deployed to the hilt, it is the action pieces taking our breath away, the go-for-the-jugular (joints, limbs, and other more cardinal parts) pragmatism and Evans' lenience on blood and guts, skewered together one set piece after another, our rapt attention becomes a given, and the brutal aesthetics reaches its crescendo in the close-range combat between Rama, his brother Andi (Alamsyah) and Tama's top muscle, a disheveled Mad Dog (Ruhian, who is a martial art virtuoso and the fight choreographer for both movies, also plays a completely different character in the sequel). After REDEMPTION successfully testing the water, THE RAID 2: BERANDAL (which means thug in Indonesian) is expectedly souped up by a significantly boosted budget and an ampler length (150 minutes, 50 minutes longer than the first installment). Mapping out an ambitious gangster turf war saga, Evans' script swiftly sends Rama to the joint to befriend Uco (Putra), the son of Bangun (Pakusadewo), one of the two kingpins of Jakarta's underworld, where a muddy mêlèe during a downpour set alight the first frisson of excitement (it is a virtue Evans doesn't overuse the worn- out slo-mo shtick, after THE MATRIX 1999 and its countless emulators, enough is enough). In fact, the resultant story veers more towards Uco's ill-conceived subversion, and Putra, not quite a martial artist himself but commendably takes up the gauntlet as a pompous gilded youth, too thrusting and wanting both wits and patience to mellow into a rightful heir of his father's cosmic empire, particularly when there is nothing to imperil his standing, what is the fuss anyway? Maybe like in every patriarch's incubus, he is just a bad seed and driven at lengths to carry out a patricidal sin, Putra's performance is vehement, visceral and transforms Uco as the film's heart of matter, a grab bag of what is wrong with today's youngsters. In the action section, on the one hand, Evans continues choreographing striking fighting sequences of Pencak Silat, and playing up the possibility of orchestration within a two-by-four space (a prison bathroom, or inside a barreling car); on the other hand, in tandem with an enclosed fistfight, he also cuts his teeth into a sterling car chase set piece with an ace in his sleeve, and what an adrenaline rush it spurs! Although it would be remiss of me to not mention a congenital hiccup rather common in action fares, those conspicuous ready-to-take-the-hit poses or caesuras, mostly from foot soldiers during their meager screen-time, it immediately dispels the "realness" of all the onerously rehearsed teamwork. The most pyrotechnic eye-catcher is indubitably the final showdown between Rama and the karambit-knives-wielding killer, credited as the Assassin (Rahman), which makes Very Tri Yulisman's Baseball Bat Man and Julie Estelle's Hammer Girl quite bathetic in their gore-fest, not to mention the boss who prefers heavy weaponry but is inept enough to toss it to the wrong one when the crunch comes.Both movies are cracking genre pieces made with labor of love, devotion and dexterity, and Evans' directorial flair takes a crucial peg up under the sequel's grander scale, blissfully, one can see the potential in a filmmaker which can unbridle the genre parameters.
An Indonesian action film that stays entertaining throughout. No filler or boring scenes. I suggest you watch it.
Great action movie. suspenseful throughout, lots of great scenes. the hand to hand combat was superb and very creative. fast and hard-hitting. this is a straight action movie (3 viewings)

Move over John Woo, the mantle of top action film director has been passed to Gareth Evans. This is the most stunning and exciting action film I have seen in forever and a day. This reminded me of being ten years-old and watching Kung Fu Theater, showing on a UHF station on and old black and white TV. If you are a fan of action movies go and see this film right now.Indubitably, this is like a shot of adrenalin straight to the heart of the action film genre. I plan on checking out the other two films in director Evans' filmography, Merantau and Footsteps.check out our full review at 3guys1movie.com

'The Raid: Redemption' is an action-packed film, about the good fighting the evil. Well-Made & agreeably claustrophobic, this one's A Rousing BloodBath.'The Raid: Redemption' Synopsis: A S.W.A.T. team becomes trapped in a tenement run by a ruthless mobster and his army of killers and thugs.Before I write any further, let me know inform the Faint-Hearted to stay miles away from 'The Raid: Redemption'.
