The brutality from start to end, will put you off completely. I myself looked from the screen, due to its relentless violence. But, for action-junkies, 'The Raid: Redemption' is their orgasm. I mean, wow! The Action-Sequences are brilliantly performed & executed. Each & Every Stunt packs a punch. The Action, here, is simply mind blowing!On the whole, despite a few narrative hiccups, 'The Raid: Redemption' pushes the action genre ahead with a fierce kick.

This movie blew me away. Let me start by saying that this is an Indonesian production, and not a Hollywood movie. So don't expect to see anybody famous in it.This movie is wall to wall martial arts/gun fights/violence kind of movie. I have never seen a movie this intense. The violence is at every turn with every fight, and the martial arts fights are insane. This movie puts Jet Li movies to shame. Best movie i have seen that has incorporated action movie with gun fights and martial arts. Very well done.To me this movie has set the bar for martial arts action movies. Jackie Chan would be proud.Go see it, it will blow you away.

reviews.review_title: Action and suspense on a different level!
reviews.content: This movie took me by surprise!!! I am a novice to Asian cinema other than the Ong Bak series of movies and older martial arts movies but, after seeing this movie, I find myself becoming immersed more into movies from Indonesia and other Asian countries! Simply put, the characters were written, and portrayed so well that it instantly made me connect with them and the movie!!! The plot was inspired and indeed, copied in such movies as the remake of Dredd but not nearly as well done as it is in this movie!!! Rama's character is so heroic as the policeman trying to do the right thing and serve justice!!! The villain is equally as impossible to ignore! To a Westerner like myself,the Indonesian language can sound so damned sinister if spoken by a true artist! I was impressed with every minute of this movie and the creative fight scenes were intense!!!!!! Next level stuff portrayed on the screen with a brilliant, pulse-pounding plot!!!! I loved it!!!!

This Indonesian martial arts action movie should get much more attention it has obtained so far, although subtitles or dubbing do naturally decrease the audience in many countries. The director and screenwriter Gareth Evans (Welsh, but residing in Indonesia) has giftedly created a plot where violence, action and bursts are naturally within - a special police squad arrive at an apartment block in Jakarta's slums run by a hard crime and drug lord, with most of residents depending on or protected by him. In such a way, an exciting and memorable movie can begin without a long introduction and without the need for show other places of action but this building.Fights are fast and visually alluring: but so is this traditional martial art called pencak silat. As the main actor Iko Uwais (young officer Rama) has won National Silat Championship, it is no wonder... And he can really act, more than early Steven Seagal or Michael Dudikoff, for example. The other fighting talent is Yayan Ruhian as Mad Dog.Thus, if you like martial arts, intensive scenes and violence without playful undertone, this movie is definitely for you!

reviews.review_title: Thrill a minute action spectacular of a kind Hollywood won't make anymore
reviews.content: STAR RATING: ***** Saturday Night **** Friday Night *** Friday Morning ** Sunday Night * Monday MorningIn Jakarta, Indonesia, a SWAT team mount a drugs raid on a tower block where a ruthless dealer and his henchmen operate. Expecting a routine bust, they under-estimate how ruthless the criminal is prepared to be and how much of an effective army he has at hand, and find themselves trapped in a massive concrete jungle, where martial arts killers lurk at every corner and only one side will take more casualties. One cop (Ido Kuwais) must race against time to save the day.With the advent of CGI and wire fu, the novelty of genuine martial artists, such as Steven Seagal and Jean Claude Van Damme, performing their on screen daring do in Hollywood has lost it's edge, with us now living in a day and age where anyone can be a martial artist. So thank Heavens we can still turn to Asian cinema, which still makes a big deal out of showcasing the real deal. While stars from the past, such as Jackie Chan and Jet Li, seem to have left more of a legacy behind them than more recent discoveries such as Ong-bak's Tony Jaa, there is a new hope in the shape of Ido Kuwais, the lead star of this new raved about action piece, and his exponing of the fighting art of Silat, which this film shows in it's fastest, most breath taking and thrilling style.Director Gareth Evans, whose previous two features appear to be even more unknown and off the beaten track than this one, generates a genuine air of suspense and claustrophobia as events unfold, with the viewer really feeling locked in with the cops as they learn just how fu*ked they are and how everyone isn't telling the truth. The fight choreography is extremely impressive, displaying a real skill for the art while not forgetting to make it as fast, brutal and thrilling as it can be. Kuwais doesn't especially stand out as an action hero, but portraying a fairly generic Asian action star performs his duties with aplomb. In general, the script, acting and dialogue aren't first rate, but the film delivers where it was supposed to, and that's what matters.God knows the lazy cookie cutting machine that is Hollywood is re0making enough things at the moment- I'm sure their placid interpretation of this will soon be in our eyes. ****

reviews.review_title: a heart-pounding, action packed thrill ride of Indonesian traditional martial arts that will leave you breathless
reviews.content: Bruce Lee. Jet Li. Jackie Chan. Iko Uwais. OK, maybe I am getting ahead of myself putting newcomer Iko Uwais on this list, but it only takes one viewing of "The Raid: Redemption" to know how talented this martial artist is. Packing punches, kicks, blocks, and combos that will have you staring at the screen, unable to blink, Uwais and the cast of this new action feature will have you saying "wow" over and over."The Raid: Redemption" is an import from Indonesia, bringing over the Indonesian traditional martial art style to America. The film follows a SWAT team that is sent into a large apartment complex to take out a crime lord. With vicious and ruthless residents on every floor, a camera system watching their every move, and the loss of transportation or the chance for backup, this raid quickly turns into a violent bloodbath in the hallways and apartment units that has the SWAT team fighting for their lives.Iko Uwais plays Rama, a rookie SWAT team member with a pregnant wife at home. Rama is only seen as a rookie to the rest of the SWAT team, but we quickly find that this guy can kick some serious tail. After getting split up with his team and having to carry around an injured team member, Rama is caught in an action packed fight in a hallway of the complex that is a one man versus dozens situation. With brilliant martial arts, choreography, and cinematography, Rama pounds his way through villain after villain, leaving a wake of bodies behind him.This is just one of the many scenes in "The Raid: Redemption" that will have you on the edge of your seat. Starting with Uwais's choreography and fighting skills through the amazing skills shown by the rest of the cast, the film is constantly exciting and moves quickly from one foe to another and one fight to the next. What is really strong about the fights is the progression of the violence in the film. Upon entering the complex, the SWAT team and enemies fire at each other with automatic machine guns and powerful long distance weapons. These fights are not hand to hand, but a distant battle that is equally as exhilarating.To read the rest of the review (IMDb form is too small) visit: http://custodianfilmcritic.com/the-raid-redemption/

Who'd have thought that Indonisia would raise the bar when it came to action movies? 'The Raid' is hardly the most complicated film to review, but, if you're into your gunplay and marshal-arts then you can't go far wrong here. Oh, and you'll need to be okay with subtitles.Basically, the film is about a police raid on a towerblock containing some of the toughest (and deadly) criminals around. And – guess what – things don't go too well for our boys in blue. It isn't long before their bodies start piling up, leaving only our plucky new recruit (who just so happens to be damn good at kicking people) to survive and untangle the mess that's quickly building up.If you're wondering what makes this so much better than all the other action movies out there – it's the 'look' (well, for starters anyway). It has a very professional and gritty feel to it. The director (who, to my shame, I've never heard of) has obviously spent a lot of time framing each shot to give it quite a nice – almost 'arty' – feel. Then there are the fight scenes – they're meticulously choreographed and, despite being technically as unrealistic as the next marshal arts film, they are really good fun to watch.The actors are basically cast according to their looks. Bad people are ugly and good people have nice hair. However, at least everyone plays their part well and, even though all the talking is subtitled, it seems that everyone can actually act as well as is required for beating people to a pulp.There are a few twists and turns in the plot – some you may see coming, others are less obvious. But I won't go into them too much. All you need to know is that, if you're okay with subtitles and love marshal arts or action films, then you'll enjoy The Raid (and its sequel, if you're curious about that!).

Although I am not the biggest fan of foreign films but this one is different.This film is all kinds of awesome:Great action sequences that are very well choreographed,a very fast pace,Lots of gore and a simple yet effective story.The only thing that could have been changed is the end fight it should have been a one on one fight.Two on one is kind of unfair in this film compared to other films like the phantom menace,attack of the clones,etc.Regardless, this film shocked me on how good it was:my 2nd favorite film released in 2012 in the US.Every filmmaker doing action films today should use this film as an example on how to do action.

A thunder of a movie where I passed 80% of its runtime with my mouth open, eyes wide and electrified, scrolling back and forth through the tremendous martial-arts action scenes, repeatedly mesmerized by the prowesses.It is very well-acted (Iko Uwais - the best protagonist among others), superbly choreographed & edited, comes with awesome camera work & shots, with viewers basically "feeling" the full blow of bullets and hand-to-hand combats. The skinny devil antagonist was probably the best out of the herd with blinding techniques and his body connected to a power station!A way underrated movie, one of the best out there in terms of martial arts techniques & choreography combined with a smooth forceful flow like an engorged spring river. Some cliche and cheesiness are scattered throughout which absolutely doesn't ruin the amazing sensations that this movie provides.Highly recommended to lovers of crazy action martial arts thrillers who haven't seen this Indonesian gem yet!Screenplay/story: 7Direction/development: 9Realism: 9.2Entertainment: 9.4Acting: 8.5Cinematography/filming: 9Visuals/special effects: 9.4Music/score: 9.1Depth: 7Logic: 7Flow: 9.4Action/thrill: 9.6Ending: 7.

NOTE: Certain elements of this review may be an inaccurate reflection of the content of the film due to the fact that I was asleep during large parts of it. Unusually for me I will start by summarising the plot. I've ticked the spoiler box even though I don't think it's possible to spoil this film for anyone. We're in Indonesia (I know that from reading other reviews). A bunch of 20 policemen lay siege to a building for reasons unknown and alternately wander around looking anxious or getting into fights. Just over 100 of these 20 men are killed in the first battle. Some of the people you think are on one side are actually on the other side but you won't care by the time you work this out. It might be worth mentioning the cop who is supposed to be the hero has a pregnant wife (that's the entire emotional setup of the film BTW). At one point he discovers one of the bad guys is either his brother or his long lost gay lover, I forget which. I am, not for the first time, mystified. This film is getting rave reviews all over the place, even in the so-called quality press. I have no idea why. Supposedly it's non-stop action all the way. In fact it's boring wondering about scene, fight, stop, wonder around a bit more, fight, repeat. The action is constantly interrupted and the film never gathers momentum. I think most of my sleeping took place in the first twenty minutes of the film whilst I was waiting for something to happen. The thing that might interest you as a fan of martial arts films is the occasional (and I mean occasional) time we get to see a form of Indonesian martial art that is largely unknown in the West before this film. It is indeed potentially exciting and would probably work well in a film with a plot. As it is, the scenes in this film are rather like the scenes from a British TV programme "The Fast Show" where two men fight each other endlessly in dockland, they never give up and they get up every time and we never know why they are fighting. The fight scenes here are additionally spoiled by a) shaky cam and b) characters often stop to exchange guns for fists to give the opponent a fighting chance or wait patiently in the wings for their turn. In one scene one fighter spends several minutes strangling another he's already beaten to a pulp whilst a third guy gets it together to stop him. Nobody expects realism in martial arts but this is ridiculous. Like Peter Bradshaw in the Guardian I will quote Bruce Lee from Enter the Dragon: "We need emotional content.." You won't get it in this deeply boring and repetitive film though I can recommend it if you suffer from insomnia. And just so you know, I am a massive fan of martial arts films and I could name at least a hundred better examples than this dreck off the top of my head. PS I'm never comfortable being this rude about a film that people have sweated over but given the adoration it's getting elsewhere, I feel justified in giving the other side of the story. PPS Women fighters don't exist in Indonesia, apparently, even though they are a staple of martial arts films from countries with a real tradition of making such films.

reviews.review_title: One of the most satisfying action movies I've seen in a while.
reviews.content: I'll get my minor issues with this movie out of the way now. The dialogue is not very good and the story isn't either apart from one element concerning 2 characters. And the dubbing isn't why the dialogue is bad, but the dubbing itself isn't good either. But other than that I got to say that this is one of the craziest martial arts action films I have seen, possibly ever. Outstanding fight choreography from beginning to end. There's a good deal of gun play and slicing and dicing in here but the hand-to-hand fighting is where this stands out for me. There are a few scenes where there isn't any chaos going on but those scenes don't make me feel as if the movie is being slowed down. IMDB says it's 101 minutes, and that seems about right. It's not overly long. And while I was expecting a twist, it ended up being from a character that I didn't expect it from. Another one didn't exactly surprise me too much, even though I didn't predict it. I only say that because as far as plots go in movies like this, this one is kind of basic apart from the setting that the movie takes place in. I gotta see the sequel, because I hear that one is even better. This was insane.

The Raid is probably the closest cinematic translation of a '80s beat-em-up arcade game possible. The story, such as it is, involves an elite SWAT team in over their heads fighting through an apartment complex full of gang members with only their elite martial arts and an ever-changing mix of weapons to help them.That undersells the movie somewhat, as the style is very carefully developed, and making great action takes a hell of a lot of work. And if there's one thing you can count on The Raid for, it's great action, with the highlight of it all being an extended three-way fight scene that's simply a joy to behold. Watching The Raid, you go through stages: amazed at the action; then overwhelmed, disgusted, and vaguely bloated from the carnage; then back to enjoying the violence again.To be honest, I probably couldn't describe much of this movie's plot to you. The attempts at plot twists are kind of hard to understand, and don't really add up to much. But as a sheer visceral experience, The Raid excels.

reviews.review_title: Blood spurts, bones snap, skulls implode, furniture explodes
reviews.content: At last, we have it: The first ten star film of the year. I was worried it might never happen. Then came The Raid.I'm not a fan of kung fu-type films and, whilst I admire Jackie Chan and appreciate he's incredibly skillful at what he does (i.e. not the acting!) his work leaves me cold. I'm not a fan of the protracted fights and the overriding feeling of watching a pantomime fight scene. And so I'd probably have ignored The Raid had it not been for an article I stumbled upon some months ago about a Welshman making an Indonesian film with a non-actor. The journalist thought, from the scenes he'd watched shooting, that it just might rock. Big time.It does. And more than that! I was quite literally stunned, jaw almost on the floor at times, and I will heartily recommend to all who care to listen. However, please note two points: 1. It is subtitled and, inexplicably, that appears to be a huge obstacle for some people (plebs! ☺) and 2. It is extremely violent. If those are issues, don't bother reading on and cross it off your list immediately.The Raid is a beautiful, nay, exquisite, bloody ballet. The choreography is mind-blowing in its intricacy and balance and the physical performances are mesmerizing. Blood spurts, bones snap, skulls implode, furniture explodes, gunfire hammers through walls, wood and flesh and the language, such as it is, has the deepest hue of blue. Be warned, it isn't an easy ride but the journey is a pleasure that must be repeated. A sequel is planned but why wait around when the original is begging to be watched again? The premise is simple: A decrepit tower block has become a haven for a crime lord, his violent minions, those who can ill-afford more desirable neighbourhoods and any number of petty thugs who chose safety within rather than without. A police chief launches a raid on the block with a team of raw(ish) recruits with the task of killing the kingpin and avoiding their own demise. Needless to say, all does not go according to plan. However, one of the cops, Rama (Iko Uwais) has no intention of dying and his own agenda to follow.The story goes that Welsh director Gareth Evans discovered martial arts champion Uwais while shooting a documentary in Indonesia and persuaded him to quit his job as a driver to star in a film written around his talent, namely The Raid. When you watch The Raid (there's no if about it, go and see it!) you'll understand why Evans went to such efforts. Understand before you go into the cinema that they shot in real time. There are no special effects to speed up the fighting. It's a blur because Uwais and his co-stars are that fast! It's almost a relief that it runs at only 101 minutes because I don't think my eyes could take much more.There are no complexities with the plot, dialogue is light and the subtitles do not in anyway hinder the viewing (for those plebs who ignored me and are still reading). It's a fast, loud, blistering assault on the senses where the music, whilst perfectly selected, plays second fiddle to the soundtrack of grunts, crashes and explosions. The foley artists earned their money on this one! I'm not going to wax lyrical about the editing, the cinematography, the casting, the physical effects, the set If I haven't persuaded you that The Raid is a 'must see' by now, nothing else I write will do so. And if I have, you'll find out for yourselves. One thing I will highlight is the end credit sequence. As a credits geek (it's a big no-no to talk through them or leave before they end and for me to do so is a protest at how awful a film is) they were a joy to read. There are no 'extras', no gimmicks or effects, just a list of character names and numbers the like of which I've never seen before.There are some who will condemn The Raid for it's content, subject matter and ability to delight with such extreme displays of armed and unarmed combat. If any of them are still reading, I'll leave you with a précis of a conversation I had as I left the cinema.As the lights went up, Marieke drew my attention to two ladies, two septuagenarian ladies, who had watched through to the bitter end. I raced after the couple to engage them in conversation and, as I reached them, they were nonchalantly discussing chopping up food in order to make it easier to swallow."Excuse me. I'm sorry to disturb you but, without wising to be rude, you're not the demographic one would expect to see in The Raid and I wondered, um, what are you doing here?" They smiled and took great pleasure in informing me, in broad Bristolian accents, that they'd read a glowing review in The Guardian and that The Watershed was screening it. "If The Watershed is showing it, it must be good. It's just much cheaper here." We discussed the film for perhaps ten minutes and it was clear that they saw beyond the violence and the language and saw the extreme beauty of the craftsmanship that went into every aspect of The Raid. For them it was the most challenging film they'd seen so far this year and one of the most rewarding.And if I didn't respect them enough for their opinions of the film and their enjoyment of TV delights The Killing, Borgen and Spiral, they certainly rocketed in my estimation with the last word I shall give them here: "We had a lot more fun tonight than we did last week in that awful film, what was it, oh yes, The Lucky One."Another film review from The Squiss.Like the Facebook page: http://on.fb.me/RpitOG

This Indonesian USA flick is a must see only for the fights going on.
