reviews.review_title: Brutal and not for the faint of heart
reviews.content:
(2012) The Raid: Redemption
(In Indonesian With English subtitles)
ACTIONA group of about 17 to 19 Indonesian SWAT team enter a no-cops-allowed building of about 15 floors to bring down a powerful Indonesian cartel. Starring some of the same cast members who starred in Gareth Evans other effort "Merantao" released in 2009, leading the way of course, Iko Uwais as Rama, Donny Alamsyah as Andi, Yayan Ruhian as Mad Dog who also happens to be the one of the fight choreographers as well, to name a few... If I'm judging this by the action sequences alone, this is the rating I'd give it since I've seen better, particularly from Jackie Chan, John Woo, Corey Yuen Kwai, and Yuen Woo-Ping and many more whose consisted to show action choreography that are charismatically filmed with camera angles that can motivate viewers to watch them multiple times and on multiple levels. "The Raid: Redemption" is better than writer / director Gareth Evans previous effort 2009 film "Merantao" which is close to rendition carbon copy of Tony Jaa's "Ong-Bak", except that "Ong-Bak" consisted to have dangerous stunts and not just the hard hitting fighting. I liked this film very much but it's not better than Tony Jaa's intricate action movie of "The Protector" because the stunts overall are much harder to perform, and are also more creative. The pattern for action films is not just good fighting but also about how they're camera filmed as well, and they're many scenes which the fights looked extremely dangerous to perform but the impact isn't always felt the same way. One fight in particular which needed two SWAT men to defeat him whose kind of a henchman but is extremely tough even though his other two opponents are taller and heavier.

I decided to see this movie because I heard about of the second and by the average votes so high. How can a film have votes so high and I had never even heard of it? Unfortunately I live in Italy. Anyway coming to the film definitely was a nice surprise. Action action and more action what I've always sought in an action movie. But all is not limited to the classic scenes of a classic film of this kind but you get to the level of brutality and in my opinion fantastic realism. Despite the frenzy the scenes run off very fluid. Obviously and unfortunately the weak point of this film as in many others of the genre is the plot, I understand that is not the central point of the film, and in fact there fly over because it was not what I was looking for and I knew what I was expecting but trying to create a story at least decent do not think is a request so exaggerated. Curious to see the second.Ultimately if you want a film of pure action and pure really mean that, this is the film for you.7/10

reviews.review_title: orgasmic display of carnage and testosterone filled mayhem!
reviews.content: The Raid: Redemption: a film so hard hitting, so full of testosterone, that really make you feel manly while watching it The Raid: Redemption is high on testosterone and adrenaline, with fight scenes brutal and bloody enough to satisfy the most hard-core action junkie.20 Elite elite commando Cops in black bulletproof vests is assigned the task of take down a Mob Boss. Once inside the building, the cops realizes that they are trapped with no way out of the building, engaging in the raid almost immediately and finding themselves outnumbered and outgunned, stumble into the midst of a massacre. What follows is a grueling one and a half hour of struggle which involves everything from bursting cylinders to machetes, to blood curdling fist fights, alpha male warriors getting their heads smashed into walls, their kidneys punched a couple dozen times, and their necks snapped back, wild warriors keep going with a jagged segment of a broken fluorescent tube sticking out of their necks! Its 101-minute fusillade of punching,head-spinning, heart-pounding, , kicking, stabbing, slashing, cracking, crunching, grouting and spurting.The group of SWAT police , a full equipped force, decked out head to toe in black uniforms, heavy tactical boots, ballistic vests, and helmets. Those alpha macho imposing uniforms begin to degrade as they're shred piece by piece over the course of the film. Rama, a virile macho cop armed with a standard-issue police baton and combat knife. He had an assault rifle and hand gun, but has discarded both after running out of ammo. Also still wearing most of his riot gear: flak vest, elbow & knee pads, but no helmet. While others get slammed harshly into walls and door, Rama stuns some thug with a club to the chest then reaches around to stab him in the back of the thigh. He stabs another in the upper thigh and then pulls the still-inserted blade nearly down to his knee. He stabs another right in the knee and then twists the knife. Throats get not just sliced but also clubbed in a enraged fury violence! The Raid: Redemption is Rambo's wet dream. It's the motivation behind John Matrix's blood lust on Commando, saw blade attacks to the skull, limb penetrating machete karate chops, and axe-to-groin devastation in a orgasmic display of carnage and testosterone filled mayhem! Especially when Mad Dog has the gun on the cop's head, puts it away and challenges him to hand to hand combat. Wow!!! Like what I read in a movie review: ". The Raid tries to have a 45 minute long orgasm Best action movie I've seen in years, most guys at the theater were having an orgasm every time someone got blown up".

reviews.review_title: Pure violence. That's why you'll love it
reviews.content: I bumped into it while I was changing TV channels. It got me good when I saw all the violence being thrown at me from the screen, so I decided I should at least watch it till the end. When the film ended, I felt like I experienced all the fights myself - my breathe was fast as I ran a mile, and I even had sweat on my forehead, thinking to myself "Now that was a ride!". I liked it, but I wasn't ready to say something about it - it wouldn't be very objective, and there wasn't anything to say except "OH MY GOSH IT WAS FREAKIN' INCREDIBLE".And so, a week or two later I re-watched it and liked the film even more. I wasn't paying attention to details during my first watch, but this time I saw much more then just a huge fight.Firstly, I would like to mention that I have never seen such creative camera work in action-packed films. All these shaky camera moves, Dutch angles in moments they were needed and some really clever shots - all this was highly innovative and 2010s-fresh. Camera work really helped with creating the desperate atmosphere of SWAT team being on the edge of death and trying to survive.Secondly, the soundtrack. I haven't heard the original version, but the American one with Mike Shinoda was simply outstanding. These electronic vibes with a pinch of brostep make all the violent fights and shootings even more aesthetic and beautiful. Seeing Iko Uwais beating the crap out of gangsters gives a very satisfying feeling by itself, but with the Mike Shinoda's compositions the effect becomes two or three times better. I have to say that this film has one of a few soundtracks I really want to buy and listen to separately. I don't want to say that I don't like other films' music, but this one truly overdone the soundtrack format.And thirdly, the direction. Gareth Evans did an extremely amazing work making all the shootings, fights and sounds into one solid piece of art. Colours, decorations and the way actors played really amazed me. There wasn't much unexpected moments in the plot, but actually I don't think this really matters in action films. As long as the script doesn't have any plot holes, it works really fine. I personally liked the themes this film talks about, though it may occur as a bunch of clichés to somebody. All the effects were great enough too, considering the budget the film used.To sum up, I'd love to say that this film feels like a roller- coaster (in a good way). There is not much plot twists, but it's not really necessary. You'll get that much adrenaline in your blood, you won't need any serious dialogues, which are pretty good, anyway. If you want to experience some action and excitement, this film is definitely your choice.

A truly excellent first film. This director understands several concepts essential to success- keep it simple until you have the resources to do something more complex, which he is clearly able to do; satisfy fans of a genre that has turned to rubbish (action-martial arts) by delivering a film that contains the goods (inventive, violent fight scenes); set it in a place we don't see all the time (Jarkarta, Indonesia) with fighting styles and faces that aren't familiar, but should be; and finally, it avoids the need for genre-spliced, twist-ended, or hip meta context. Its just a good, no, great action movie. I can't wait to see more from this director.

reviews.review_title: The Raid: Redemption : A relentless action film with high body count
reviews.content: Its simple premise does not seem to make sense much at the beginning. An Indonesian SWAT team is dispatched to one of the most dangerous places in the city. It is a shabby 30-story building somewhere in the slum area, and we are informed that this is the headquarter of a notorious drug lord named Tama(Ray Sahetapy), who lives on the 15th floor while filling the building with his violent gangs as the landlord. I do not know why he chooses the 15th floor, but I know the movie would be longer if he lived on the 30th floor.And I do not understand why there are not more policemen to surround or infiltrate into this building. If they know that the building is not an easy place to attack at all, then why are only around 20 members of SWAT team sent to this place with only one riot van? Can't they accomplish their mission in a far safer way with more supports? The movie later reveals a hidden motive behind this mission, but I am rather amazed that the people incidentally not shown in the movie cannot think of a quieter way of taking care of their private problem with a far less body count.But never mind, folks, because the movie is all about actions to be generated from this barebone premise, not the plausibility of the plot. Under the command of the team leader(Joe Taslim), the SWAT team members quickly go inside the building and move upward carefully while not being noticed. Everything seems to go smoothly at first, but the building has many eyes including the cameras in the hallways and little boys, so they are eventually exposed and all hells break loose upon them instantly. Tama shuts down the entire building along with the communication line(my god, doesn't any of SWAT team member have a cellular phone just in case?) and then announces the killing time for his guys in the building.Once the first shooting starts inside the building, the movie hurls the characters into the series of frantic actions with no mercy. Besides the guns, the characters in the movie also use big knives and other objects available around them, and there are lots, lots, and lots of fights and killings happening here and there in the building. Out of curiosity, I checked my wristwatch, and I found at least more than 20 guys were already killed or injured during the first 30 minutes. And that was just a tip of iceberg; there were a lot more violence awaiting for me and the audiences during the rest of the running time, and I already felt numb with this continuing savageness when I watched in disbelief one character who kept fighting with two dudes while a piece of broken fluorescent light bulb was stuck in his neck. Ugh.I was impressed by the rapid and ferocious energy pulsating inside the fight sequences in the film. Most of SWAT team members are quickly killed by thugs, and the rest of them, including the team leader and a rookie member named Rama(Iko Uwais), try to escape from the building by any means necessary. As our hero, Rama fights with the bad guys many times for saving himself and others, and, choreographed by the Indonesian martial art experts Iko Uwais and Yayan Ruhian(he played Tama's fearsome top lieutenant in the movie), these fights sequences feel real, electrifying, and sometimes scary. We can see that the actors on the screen are really fighting while using their body parts in spite of frantic camera movement, and, when the end credit was rolled, I was rather relieved to know that the movie hired 14 doctors and paramedics during the production.Yes, I worried to some degrees about the actors rapidly going through these dangerous actions, but what about the characters played by them? Well, I have to say there is not much of characterization in the shallow plot which barely supports the actions in the movie. Rama is given some background at the start, but it is not so important to the plot except giving us the reason why we want him to survive through his plight. His wife is pregnant, so we do not want to see a baby without his killing machine dad in the photo, right?It goes without saying that the other characters besides Rama are more or less than cardboards to be shot or stabbed or slashed or smashed or slaughtered or whatever. There is some melodrama element from the hidden bond between two characters in the plot, but there is no surprise in that. The dialogues are mostly perfunctory amid or between the sound and fury in the soundtrack, and the most memorable line in the movie will be "Ahhhhhhhhhhh!" or "Arrrrrrrrgh!". I was particularly amused by the cast list, which mostly consists of the nameless characters like "Special Force #16", "Carrying Bowo Fighter #18", "Drug's Lab Guard #21", "Hole Drop Attacker #8", and so on. Suppose you appear in the movie – can you boast to your friends about appearing as, uh, "AK-47 shooter #3"?Should I evaluate the movie as a ruthless but exhilarating ballet of martial arts, or a well-made but pointless rampage of brutal action? My feeling remain ambivalent due to its inherent weak points, but the director/writer/editor Gareth Evans made a competent action movie, and Iko Uwais is fully functional and professional as its action hero. His character is thin, but at least we can see how he uses his brain as well as his body in the chaotic circumstances, and I liked his actions more than, say, "Transformers 3". However, I also remember what Roger Ebert wrote in his review for "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragoon"(2000): "The best martial arts movies have nothing to do with fighting and everything to do with personal excellence."

Normally I don't like full on action films as the scenes with action in it tends to have quick editing, shaky cam, over the top explosions and witty yet cheesy dialogue. However, after I saw the Raid I was taken aback as none of the things that I listed above was in this movie which was absolutely astounding. There's so much clarity among the fight scenes that it almost feels like you're there with the fighters. The film is beautifully directed, I can't see any other way for it to be so for the stupid remake. Not only has this changed the action genre in a significant way it also made me appreciate foreign films more. Yes, there are bad things about this movie but imo they are very minor and the way this movie was shot makes you look pass that. Watching all those kung fu flicks when Evans was a boy, paid off for him in this and his previous film, Merantau. Kudos to you sirPeople keep saying that this is the best action film since Ong Bak, in no way is it the best film since Ong Bak, its the best film in decades. Ong is quite cringe worthy because of the acting that is displayed on screen and also because of the overused slo mo effect the director used when Jaa did something 'cool'. There are parts within the Raid that has slo mo in them but Evans made sure it was used in the most necessary wayIgnore the review that Roger Elbert had given this movie (1/4 stars) as he clearly doesn't understand nor appreciate a well made film that proves that you don't need to have much depth in your characters or in your story. Though he does point out some NOT all good reasons as to why the film wasn't for him but some of these reasons are beyond ridiculous. This movie was beyond my expectations, it was beautifully directed and the fight scenes were very much believable, the guy who did the sound effects for the punches and the kicks should also be thanked for it to be believable as s/he didn't use those effects where you could obviously tell that those punches or kicks didn't land.Thank u Mr Evans for showing Hollywood that you don't need a billion dollar budget to make a good action flick and needing such a sophisticated storyline and character depth and that all you need is to be smart at what you do.OK the ones who say that there is shaky cam in the fight sequences are freakin retarded, I couldn't even see the camera shaking when the fight scenes were on, they were as clear as day. Also, people saying 'oh everyone in the building knows some type of martial arts, how typical' in their review or on the discussion board needs to watch this film again, NOT everyone knew how to fight it was only some. If you think that holding and shooting a gun, wielding a machete around or throwing a couple of punches is some form of martial arts then wow you must have an IQ of a room temperature.

This is as good as it gets in terms of pure action and martial arts movies go. The Raid is the introduction to most people to Iko Uwais, who is one of the best martial arts actors on the planet right now. Everything is stellar from start to finish, some of the best choreographed fight scenes ever on film.

This was one year ahead of Dredd 2012 film. They have a lot of similarities. But what makes Serbuan Maut, the slightly weaker one. Is that it is a sausage fest, and lacks the sci-fi elements. It had better martial arts, but was overall more boring.

I did Karate for seven years, so it's only natural that I like good action films; in fact, I love them. I have a special spot in my heart for Bruce Lee, of course, but he didn't make that many movies. Jackie Chan and Tom Cruise are probably my two favorite action actors of all time; not only do they do their own stunts, which are insane, by the way, but they nail their acting parts to the teeth as well.Anyways, while looking for good action films, this film was listed very high in dozens of lists and held in a very high standard as an instant action film classic. Did it live up to my expectations? Well holy crap, it did.Let's go with the positives first:The action. Oh my God, the action in this film. From a technical aspect, it's perfectly filmed, amazingly edited and beautifully choreographed, with a very raw, desperate, tense and urgent feeling to each confrontation. It's brutal. It doesn't hold back in any way, but it isn't gory or graphic in unnecessary ways, but rather in a more realistic manner. You feel every hit landing. Its as if one were there with the troopers. Its very clear that the actors do their own fighting, too. The action here is amazing.The acting: special kudos to Joe Taslim and some of the other soldiers. Taslim transmits perfectly the anguish, pain, rage, and stress that would come from being in a situation like this, and his fight scenes are amazing. Iko Uwais was amazing in the action front, but his acting is not nearly as solid as the aforementioned JT; that being said, he does quite a good job.The atmosphere: its tense. You feel the suspense. Anything could happen, and anyone could die at any moment. Its gritty and realistic.And now, lets go with the one issue this movie has, which is that the story is not as solid, and there are some subplots which I will not spoil that could be more effective if given a little more time and the acting were a little better.In conclusion, this is an amazing movie. A true must see for any action junkie or martial artist out there.

"In the Jakarta slums, a derelict apartment building has become a no-go area - even the police are unwilling to enter. It has become a safe-house for the most dangerous killers and gangsters. A SWAT team infiltrate the building, under the cover of darkness, to remove its owner - a notorious drug lord named Tama." This is the plot synopsis for an interesting action movie. Overall, I enjoyed the movie very much. The reason why I didn't give it a higher score was because the plot was not very deep and because some of the dialogue was a little cheesy.Other than that, this was a very fun movie to watch. It is brutally violent throughout with a lot of cool action scenes with some pretty sweet martial arts moves.Overall, if you are prepared for mindless violence, this is the movie for you. Enjoy.

reviews.content: I read some wrote the Star Wars of Action Movies. Others wrote other action movies are snack. I agree. I mean Star Wars is to sci-fi as Raid Redemption is to Action Movies. The plot was minimalistic. Usually action movies are but this was almost non existent. Why did almost every single person in this movie know some form of martial arts. At first it felt like playing the first Resident Evil game or something along those lines but it was just one fast paced fight after another. Admittedly the gore was done quite well but there should have been some serious re-writes for this movie as it had some pacing issues. Yes we get it our hero knows how to fight but take a hostage like the chief of polices daughter, the heroes wife.. something! Instead of us just blindly going in like we're playing the nintendo game Kung Fu from 1984.Usually I don't check my emails or anything along those lines but watching a movie like this was an exception. It's to the point you just get bored of all the fighting. The snipers I felt weren't used enough. Sure there are buildings with more than 4 sides but what was stopping them from moving to another vantage point especially at a point of them movie where we forget that they are there. What did they have to go pick up their kids from school? Was it time for a nap? Did the sleazy looking boss only give them 4 rounds each. The ending was just lazy and that final fight scene with skinny greasy guy and the two went on wayyyy too long. You could use the washroom or make ramen noodles, boil the water and everything and the fight would still be going. II found that there were members of the gang that didn't look tough enough and the people under the boss didn't seem tall. Muscular or scary enough. At least the hero actually got injured in fights not like the worlds greatest actor of all time Steven Seagal. My favorite scene in this had to be the machete going through the wall but this was just bland. Unless you've only seen like 5 or 10 action movies it's so boring where the saving grace is the gore. Is it just me or is the poster wrong? They said 30 floors but there isn't.

reviews.review_title: good action movie...a very good one!
reviews.content: We've seen a lot of review and hype about this movie, esp here in IMDb.I, too, was a victim of hype from IMDb and some other forum and media.All those warnings are true, you don't come and watch the raid to enjoy the story, the plot, the characters, you come to enjoy the ACTION!So for those who've read the reviews and knew the hype but still complaining about story, etc...well, I don't think you could read then..Anyway, going into the movie, I was having a very high expectation for the action in this movie and I was a bit skeptic that this movie will meet that expectation (crouching tiger hidden dragon which get great review and hype back then was an HUGE disappointment for me).The first few minutes I was sighing at my seat as the plot and the acting is really hurting my eyes and brain (again, you should watch this movie without have to think about the common sense/logic).Then when the action came, especially after they stop using guns and start to do hand to hand combat, it is one hell of a ride.It actually met my high expectation for the action and combat scene, I didn't even dare to blink when it's combat scene since it was really fast paced and intense and I'm afraid if I were to blink, I would miss some of the detail in the combat scene.I especially love the way they used the knife, and aside from not able to blink, I unconsciously clenched my fist during some of the fight scene since it's really intense and making your adrenaline pump! Well..that is until the fight stops near the end of the movie where the plot started to make my eyes and brain hurting again :pI gave 10 out of 10 only for the action part. I would give this movie 1- 2 for the acting and plot, lol, but hey, we're looking for action, aren't we? And if you're looking for 1, make sure you watch this one! :)

A group of special forces came to storm an apartment that became a residence and headquarters for the criminals of the capital. Their mission is simple, catch one of the number one criminal criminals who became the owner of the apartment and return safely.This is one of the best action films owned by Indonesia. One of the films that is starting to feel like a Hollywood action movie. The Raid has an exciting and challenging story premise. The premise of the story is carried with consistent conflict until the end of the film to keep the excitement of this film. I see this film as selling more on the action side of the action than a story conflict that looks simple. It deals with several scenes that have plot holes in explaining the story and the main conflicts in this film. The Raid presents each scene by providing a sense of tension, excitement, amazement from the action shown. The action of martial arts games that become an exciting and fun fighting force to watch, ranging from bare hands to using a machete. This film also presents martial arts action as a model of fighting. Stunning combat with brutal, sadistic and crazy elements can be felt perfectly.It is worth appreciating in the acting performance of this film, starting from Iko Uwais, Joe Taslim, Yayan Ruhiyan, Donny Alamsyah to Ray Sahetapy. Excellent acting from actors who have skills in martial arts, except for Ray and Donny. As the main enemy, Ray is able to bring a character that looks intimidating with his calm and decisive nature. Yayan acts as a Mad Dog who appears crazy with his good martial arts choreo. Also at the end of the epic and incredible fight becomes the finale of this film.

Not many movies pump you and you feel energetic after a some point of elapsed time in the movie. You have to swipe a building filled with drug-lords and criminals and once you are inside, there's no way outside and the only way left is to do or die.I remember the same concept movie was Dredd but this one stole the show through it's flawless action techniques. Iko Uwais did perfect job by his fighting skills and so did Gareth Evans in direction. I also found the background music which followed with kicks and punches and was equally gripping.Good Indonesian experiment film and anytime action watch.

reviews.review_title: This is Gareth Evans' furiously paced, martial arts masterpiece.
reviews.content: When a SWAT team enters a 30-storey apartment block looking to kill a notorious crime lord, they don't realise the danger lying in wait. What seems like a routine mission on paper is anything but as it becomes increasingly apparent that the real problem is surviving long enough to get back out again.The story may seem rudimentary, but it in its brief runtime it manages to input more than enough character development to keep things from becoming stale. But... this film hasn't been designed to tell a compelling story. It's a setup for some of the most exciting and creative action sequences ever put to film, all set to the throbbing pulse of its sound design.'The Raid' is a breathtaking display of martial arts choreography; a constant sensory assault of bloodthirsty mayhem, with each floor rigged to explode into frenetic action. And Gareth Evans is well aware how to expertly stage these sequences by letting the camera linger on the fight scenes. There's no obtrusive close-ups, no rapid edits, just plenty of extended shots to showcase the talent of the individuals and their fighting techniques on camera.The violent criminals think they have things covered, but what they don't count on is Rama (Iko Uwais) not only fighting back, but messing everyone up in style. Whether using his bare hands to batter his opponents, or using the environment to bone-crunching effect, he demonstrates a skillset few people have. He's a hero worth rooting for as he turns the tables on his attackers (sometimes literally) and forges a bloody path to the top of the high-rise.Unrelenting and unforgettable, writer/director/editor Gareth Evans has taken a simple premise, executed it with flair, and turned out a masterful, memorable action thriller.

I'm not going to go into a lot of detail as there's been plenty of people who have done that already. What I will say though is that this movie is the best action movie of all time. Of course that's my opinion but this coming from someone who's in the military, trains in martial arts and has seen many action movies. The fight scene choreography is amazing and is the most realistic I have ever seen. Some people may complain that; 1. The fights are too long 2. The fighters attack too often/too much 3. Real life fighting is like (insert MMA arena tournament here) and not this movie.I will post my response to those complaints later on. Now when you start watching 'The Raid' you have to realize it's 75% martial arts, 15% gun fights and 10% story. I mean that in a good way (especially if you like action). 10% story doesn't mean the story sucks, it just means there's not much of it. The movie has a rather dark and gritty tone to it the whole time. If you want a fun and happy action movie this is definitely not it.Story: There's a drug lord who owns an apartment building and a highly trained swat team is going in to take him down.Overall there's lots of very realistic fight scenes, a couple good shoot outs and one hell of a villain toward the end. They say you buy an action movie for the action, and this movie is insanely packed with intense nonstop action from start to finish.The whole movie is in Indonesian and I recommend leaving it in Indonesian (with subtitles of course) even though you won't understand them. Why? Because the yells and screams are much more intense and believable than the English dubbing. Not to mention the English voice actors suck. They sound very cheesy and ruin the whole movie with their version of the dialog.My response to the complaints; 1. Would you rather get more for your money or get a 5 second fight for your money? Also two trained fighters are not going to be out of a fight at the first hit. 2. Real life fighting is far more aggressive, You're trying to kill the other person after all. You're not trying to 'earn a point' or 'win the match'. You're constantly trying to break or damage any part of them you can. 3. Arenas and tournaments have rules, real life doesn't.That being said, I do respect the MMA world but it's more for entertainment as far as I'm concerned.

Please don't rent this movie.Save yourself a BIG disappointment.I rented this movie because it has so many high ratings.I don't know why everyone else rates this so high.The first part of the movie is very good and interesting, but that is just the first 15/20 minutes.The rest of the movie is just a very BAD joke. Exaggerated and with bad actors.It's the same old bad movie, where the "bad guy" just won't die!Please rent any other movie, besides this bad comedy.

reviews.review_title: One of the most entertaining films there is!
reviews.content: My dad bought this movie on DVD some time ago. It looked to me to be just another average, over-the-top action movie except in a different language. But, after sitting in a press for a few days, I decided to watch it out of boredom. Best decision I'd made for quite some time!This is NOT just another average, over-the-top action movie except in a different language, this is a near perfect action movie. Some would say the action is indeed over-the-top, those people are just plain wrong. The action is beautiful, artistic even. The violence in this movie I cannot compare to any other. It doesn't rely on a brilliant plot or Oscar-worthy acting, instead relying on violence, violence and more violence. That's not to say the entire film is just fighting. We are introduced to the plot, it goes wrong and the main characters become trapped. From here, the film goes from one amazing fight scene, to a break. In this break from the action, characters are developed. Then another big action scene followed by a break. This cycle occurs three or four times in the film. While this seems rather boring, I assure you it is not. The Raid: Redemption, through accident, has become one of my favorite movies of all time and one which I am constantly recommending to everyone I can... If you haven't seen it yet and are on the fence, WATCH IT!

In these days of generic action flicks with unoriginal plots, emotionless characters and boring action, 'The Raid:Redemption' stands out as one of the few action movies that are worth seeing.This 2011 masterpiece revolves around a S.W.A.T team on a mission to raid the den of a criminal kingpin. The movie wastes no time and gets right to the point. That being, the action.The action scenes (which are not few and far between) are directed marvelously by Gareth Evans and his team. My only complaints being the amount of shaking camera in the first few action moments. Aside from that, the action is shot really well and choreographed brilliantly. We get the right balance between martial arts fights and shooting sequences. The action is realistic, despite there being a few moments which are hard for us to believe actually happened without lethal consequences for the characters involved.The acting is good for an action film and immerses the viewer into the gritty and brutal environment. My biggest mistake was that I watched the movie with English dubbing,which was horribly executed and I do not advise anyone to do so.The soundtrack was serviceable (not anything you would remember) and the pacing was good and balanced well between more intense scenes and slower, character developing ones.All in all, it was one of the best action movies I've watched in a long time and I'll surely watch it again some day.

I was stunned to see the action (Kung-fu) sequences in the movie. The action sequence at the climax was my favorite. Apart from the stunt-men, I feel the camera-work is intense and superb. I loved the bgm that added a flavor to the theme. The storyline is too simple (a group of newly trained recruits raid a building to take down a mobster) but has few twists and turns at apt points in the movie.The dialogs were ultra-reduced and not convincing. The acting is just okay, could've been better. The movie is not for kids due to gory scenes and profane words. The script could've been handled with some 'feelings' and some background on the villain.The bottom line : 'The Raid' entertains you with good action throughout with few flaws.
Although several years have passed since I watched this movie, it continues to be one of the better action films that I've watched. Recommended.

This movie can be compared to sitting down to a 15 coarse meal of all ice cream. It is lacking content but that doesn't matter because it is the best ice cream you've ever had. The action scenes in this movie are not only amazingly choreographed nut incredibly shot. You see all the action, not just a knife being plunged into a thigh during a close up shot. The Raid: Redemption has the most "HOLY HELL DID YOU SEE THAT?!!?" moments in any movie I have ever watched. All types of combat are executed brilliantly from the shootouts to the hand on hand combat. Although this movie will not captivate you with artistic ideals it will most certainly leave you glad that you chose it for your fun movie night.

reviews.review_title: Let the bodies hit the floor, wall and table.
reviews.content: The plot of "The Raid: Redemption" is beautifully simple. A SWAT team who have broken into a tower block controlled by a gang lord have become trapped inside and the few that remain must fight their way out. There are a few other subplots that drift into focus occasionally, but they are described so vaguely and have almost no relevance to the action, it's as though the filmmakers knew they were kidding themselves. All that matters here is the action.Usually I'd criticise a film for sticking to the basics and not risk being original, but it's had to care when one lone cop is taking on corridor after corridor full of opponents, using only his fists, feet and occasional knife for good measure. Audiences' queasy at the sight of blood should probably stay away; the brutality in this film cannot be exaggerated. I can't remember the last time (if ever) I have winced so loudly at what I was watching. Heads disappear into walls, knives into throats, bodies are pummelled so relentlessly it's amazing the characters don't crawl hands and knees into the next scene. Thankfully, the film is superbly directed by Brit director Gareth Evans so the action remains coherent and instead of feeling repetitive and tiresome we are left hanging for the next fight. Instead of resorting to the confused shaky cam of the generic Hollywood thriller, Evans knows when to step back and let the audience revel in the amazingly choreographed fights or other times follow the cops through holes in the floor or even as they fall three floors from a window onto a fire escape in mid-fight. (I learn that Hollywood is planning their inevitable remake which will be sure to correct this for brain dead audiences leaving Alex Cross.) We mostly stick with rookie cop Rama (Iko Uwais) as he tries to help his injured friend escape in between battering one charging tenant after another. Some people have likened this film to a video game and I don't disagree. As soon as one opponent is dispatched, another eagerly steps forward oblivious to the dark stain on the wall that seconds before was his predecessor. Even the climactic showdown with the gang leader's henchman feels much like a boss fight. Uwais deserves credit for giving Rama at least enough personality to root for him as he charges through the movie, assisted no doubt by the lazy cliché of the Pregnant Wife Back At Home. He deserves even more for his astonishing martial art skills, which are easier to simply watch in awe than for me to describe.Some people will criticise this film for not bringing anything new to the table (other than the bloody heads of tenants) in the way of character development or an interesting plot and to some extent I agree. Had the director maybe taken the time before entering the building to establish Rama's character more and build on the reason for them being there I probably would have admired "The Raid: Redemption" even more. But there are times when I really couldn't care less whether a movie transcends its genre or provides me with an emotionally enriching experience. I just want to see s#!t beat up.As a side note, the "Redemption" in the title can't help but feel irrelevant, unless redemption involves killing a lot of people or it is just establishing the possibility of a "Raid" franchise. If the latter is true, count me in.

reviews.review_title: A good action film, but just a decent film overall
reviews.content: The Raid is a simple story about a SWAT team that has been sent out to take down the infamous criminal Toma, who's the owner of an apartment building filled with thugs. After the team has arrived and got into this tenement, they become trapped inside the building and escaping the building seems to be harder than it was to get intoThis film was directed very well by Gareth Evans who created a good looking movie, well, good not necessarily good-looking color wise as they made the color grading look very dirty to capture the dark atmosphere. The framing though was really good. This is an action film as you could've guessed, so it's bound to have fighting sequences, and since this movie is praised specifically for that part, I was expecting quite a lot of this. And, did it surpass my expectations? Absolutely. They were amazing. This movie is worth watching just for the action scenes, something you don't hear a lot these days. The director obviously loved the martial arts used in the film and he translates that very well to the big screen. Gareth Evans, the director, was also keen on his use of edits as he at times didn't cut away from the action for a couple of seconds and created these amazing fighting sequences that had a fantastic flow to them. He was also able to keep these scenes easy to follow, also something not a lot of movies do right these days, by having the camera stay steady and don't cut every second. It's been a while since I've seen a movie where the stunt work was as good as it is in this one and The Raid deserves all the credit it's getting for having the best fight choreography. The whole film was practically one big action scene with some intermissions, so it would've been a shame if the action scenes were not as good as they are now. There were also these dumb moments (the fridge scene), but the film knows that those scenes are silly and they don't try to take themselves serious, which is always a good thing for a movie to do. The make-up and set design were all pretty good considering the low budget they had the work with. But those intermissions brought some problems to the table. The film has a pretty fast pace throughout the film, but stops abruptly every time there's an intermission in which they try to develop characters. I don't mind that they develop their characters, since I like to see a movie with well-rounded characters that feel like real people, but the problem is that the writing in those scenes just wasn't that good. They were mostly clichéd, like the opening sequence in which they want us to relate to the main character, but ultimately fail at doing that, because they use a technique that has been done a million times before, which is a real shame. Throughout the movie thought there are some actions he does whereby we get to know him for a bit, it's just those moments when the movie abruptly comes to a stop where the problem lays.The acting was pretty good though and they set up the villain nicely with the use of only one scene. His acting was really good and he came over really menacing. Iko Uwais, who played the protagonist, his acting was really good and because of this he made his character feel more real than the writing itself did. I did like that the characters each had their vulnerabilities to them and that they affected how they fought and not that they were able to shake it off.As you're able to see of that little description of the story it seems to be fairly simple. Not overly complicated, just straightforward and I liked that. A lot of B-movies reach for the over convoluted story to cover up the fact that theirs is simple or just dumb. In The Raid that's not the case. There's no complicated story needed and it's also not trying to cover up the fact that it's straightforward. The film knows what it is and it embraces that really hard. But that all doesn't mean that the story isn't clever. It's actually quite clever in the way the story is constructed. It's constructed like an old 80's or 90's video game, namely that you have to build your way up to the final boss-level while each level starts to get harder and harder. In the end this was an amazing action film, but just a decent film overall. The acting was good, but the characters were lacking, which obviously lays within the screenplay, which wasn't the greatest. The action scenes however were shot amazingly and the so was the fight choreography. That's why this film gets a 7.5/10.

reviews.review_title: Great fight scenes , but no story
reviews.content: as a brief describe for this movie I can say : -It's an action movie but it's problem that it doesn't have a story behind, and it suffers from lack of plot and suspense, so in some point I had a feeling that it's more close to a horror film.-It contains a lot of powerful fight sequences from all kinds(guns fight, hand to hand combat , knifes clashing..) some of them could be too long, and some is too brutal.-If you are a martial arts fan you would enjoy this movie (even-though I didn't!) but if you aren't so I don't recommend watching.Finally, I admit that it's a decent Indonesian film, and it's a big step for the Indonesian films industry, but it still needs a lot of work and improvements to become an international movie.

reviews.review_title: The best action movie ever, ever.
reviews.content: I found IMDb by researching competition for a movie quote website. This will be the first movie review I have typed on IMDb.That being said, this is the BEST action movie I have ever seen. I won't go into all the complexities that others have, I'll just say that there is NONE of the pretentiousness or expectatiousness (new word) of your heroes here. The action between the antagonists and protagonists is VERY real. The action throughout puts you into the mindset of kill or be killed... there is no expectation of outcome.The best way I can express this is, when you have a fight scene, nit will be the most realistic fight scene that you have ever seen.

I have to admit, I want to like this one. Maybe I'll sit down and watch it a third time, but people who praise this film: I really want to know what you see that I'm missing. I've watched it twice, and I just don't get it. The plot is paper thin and I'm fine with that. But the non stop action that had people cheering at movie screens? Did I miss that? Yes, there were some excellent action scenes but certainly nothing that some modern day video games haven't done already (and better I might add). Not to mention, as a fan of cinema verite/found footage films, the constant shaky cam in this is completely distracting and at times unnerving. I may just give this one a third viewing cause again, I'd really love to love this film, but unfortunately as it stands I just don't see what's so special and cannot suggest this one to others.

reviews.review_title: A movie that relies only on violence and martial art but forget about storytelling.
reviews.content: The Raid An action movie that everyone is talking about and claimed that it was a breakthrough as both action and martial art genre which is the one and only The Raid:Redemption. this movie was praised by both critics and film goers which both agreed that it is a great action movie in recent years,yet even one critics claimed that this movie has made most of Hollywood action movie into a shame since The Bourne Ultimatum. Being a breakthrough in both action movie and martial art which i can't argue about it because the movie is some kind of a breakthrough in terms of action movie rules and concept when most people(even critics) says that this movie is perfect or flawless,it is certainly not. the films is all about violence with martial arts as the main tools to make it thrilling and exhilarating,filmmaker Gareth Evans managed to use it to create some kind of symphony of street fighting which makes up most of the movie.the fighting choreograph was flawless and convincing because it looks like they really passionate about the whole process. From start to finish,The raid filled with blood pumping combat from guns battle,deadly hand to hand combat,and vicious machete duel which fuel the movie with adrenaline and excitement.A group of S.W.A.T team led by lieutenant Jaka(Joe Taslim) has been given a command to capture notorious crime lord named Tama (Ray Sahetapy) who famous for his power and ruthless behavior toward his victim.but the group consist of rookie cop including Rama (Iko Uwais) who didn't know that his latest task will change his life forever. Although full of rookie,Leutant Jaka confident that his leadership will not effected the mission to infiltrate the infamous compound which was used by Tama to protect his empire from every police that want to take him down.after they reach the compound,they begin to infiltrate the compound with caution so they couldn't be detected and their infiltration goes well until they faced a young spotter who managed to alert other spotter,eventually their mission begin to crumble when Tama traps them in the 6th floor and switch off the electricity to assassinate them one by one.The story is light and simple without not much of a twist and rather predictable,but it is also the weakest part of the movie since the plot hasn't been structured from the beginning that makes the movie didn't have a story to tell and lost its meaning since the aspect of the story is really weak. beside story what the raid didn't manage to deliver is the dialog,even thought dialog is not much important for general movie audience,but it does matter for some viewers and it is certainly important for critic,because dialog also help to make the movie has more meaning but storytelling and meaning was certainly not the priority here. aside from action sequence,the raid has nothing to offer since it almost has no plot or dialog so the character also has nothing to do beside keep fighting enemies that being thrown off constantly by the crime boss Tama,fortunately most of the actor is an expert in martial arts so their ability save them from making the character completely bland.the rising martial artist Iko Uwais was the headline of the movie because his skill make the character worth to watch.beside him,actor and fighting choreograph Yayan Ruhian should have been given credit because without him and Uwais the movie would't have the exhilarating vicious combat.despite major flaw that the movie has,the raid is fun and exciting movie to watch,watching the raid is like playing a good game that lack of story which make us curious and sympathize about the character journey,unfortunately this is what the raid doesn't have so overall the raid has nothing to impress beside its fighting sequence which is becoming monotonous as the movie progress.if you want meaningful story and unforgettable character this movie is definitely not a recommendation.

reviews.review_title: A pointless ride of nonstop gang brutality and stylized death sequences, however one the best presentations of martial arts thus far in cinema. Is it a fair trade-off?
reviews.content: My main problem with the movie is that the plot can be written entirely on a cocktail napkin. This movie is nothing more than a ride. Although make no mistake about it, The Raid Redemption is one damn good ride. The martial arts are not only of the highest standard but also fresh, like nothing you've ever seen before. If your even mildly interested in action movies then this flick will leave a mark as one of the most outrageous products to come out of Asian cinema. Except outrageous doesn't equal enjoyable to all fans. So here's the summary of the plot in one line: A SWAT team goes on an operation to invade a gang- controlled building in conquest of eliminating the leader and his conspirators which are located atop the highest floor. There you go, shut your brain off from there and watch the uncompromising display of violence. As the audience we follow Iko Uwais with his role of Rama, but as hard as the movie tries to attach us to Rama's plight by convincing us he's an honorable family man, by the end this attempt falls through because the setup to his character is only mentioned in a few lines in order to sacrifice screen time for the action. Now generally most action movies barely setup their protagonists in the beginning, but the Raid Redemption doesn't even give us enough breathing room to become accustomed to Rama along the way. In that sense the movie is only a nonstop ride of baddies getting stabbed and shot. The "twists" are some of the most clichéd possible in the genre, and the conclusion doesn't clear much up other than "F$#% yeah we're the best. Cue the slo- mo and epic music". The movie's start shoves the audience into the action then at the end abruptly takes us out once more. I felt the conclusion to be awkward and leave me numbed in hopes of further closure. Hate me for this, but I believe an intriguing story is what compliments and satisfies watching intense action. I didn't feel for Rama or his team, plus his team isn't "present enough" for me to care about them anyway. The violence sure was genuine and fit the tone, but I can't look past the flaws in the story and character development. -6/10

This film was just ghastly. I couldn't even watch it until the end. It looks like an amateur made it. Now I don't know much about how "good movies" are supposed to be, regarding cinematography, acting, effects etc. but that's not the point here. I mean, the story is ridiculous and hard to believe, you can't relate to the actors, and the whole thing is just unpleasant. I have no idea how people enjoyed this movie. I love action movies so it's not as if this isn't my type. A swat team goes on an unofficial mission and starts killing everyone in a building. If you like to watch meaningless shooting and fighting (oh and by the way somehow the all of the SWAT cops have karate skills here) then go for it. If you like the movie to have at least some depth then save yourself the trouble of watching this overrated excuse for a movie.

reviews.review_title: Great foreign movie but really still only B grade action movie
reviews.content: This is a foreign made movie(Filipino?). it is dubbed to English. Acting is action character weak. The weak acting is compounded by a dead pan dubbing to English. The karate action scenes are great rapid punches and kicks and using various objects as weapons. So a Jackie Chan style of amazing acrobatic feats. However, this is much more violent with a lot of shooting and killing and blood. So this is a very good movie considering it is foreign made but unfortunately IMDb is giving this movie a bonus 2 stars that really isn't there just because it is a foreign movie that doesn't stink.Good DVD to watch on a Sunday afternoon while doing something else. Just look up every so often and go "that was neat" then go back to what you were doing.

reviews.review_title: Slogs don't come better than this
reviews.content: The Raid promises "1 minute of romance, 99 minutes of carnage", which for anyone hungry for non-stop violence bodes extremely well. With such a rousing tagline, one envisions a bloody ballet, complete with bullets, punches, explosions and most importantly, the kinetic spirit that makes the best action films the joyfully bombastic escapades they generally are. And, to a certain extent, The Raid delivers. The action scenes are long, brilliantly choreographed, and painted with a healthy coat of thick, crimson blood. Unlike American films, each punch has consequences, and the characters seem almost human in their pain tolerance, while delightfully inhuman in every character and supporting characters' apparent mastery of kung fu.But beyond the action sequences, The Raid simply is not a good film. The plot is easily understood, but awkwardly staged, staggering from outrageous scenario to outrageous scenario without providing the viewer with the required sense of progression. The ending is abrupt, peddling a strange theme instead of the triumph I expected (and would have greatly appreciated), rendering the film the cinematic equivalent of a half-squeezed lemon. Lovingly squeezed, but half- squeezed nonetheless.The Raid tells the story of a police raid on an apartment building gone horribly wrong. After his unit is massacred and he finds himself alone and targeted by scores of machete-wielding Indonesians, Rama, a young Indonesian police officer, is forced to fight for his life. If you've seen Dredd (2012), the story is very similar, a lone warrior facing off against an army out to kill him. These films work best when the lone warrior is actually alone, like in Die Hard. John may have had help outside, but inside the building, he was alone except for his wits and his skills. In The Raid, Rama isn't completely alone, which was a poor choice by the screenwriters. It would have been much funner if he was.But beyond that, the film has little progression. Rama runs around and beats people up, reunites briefly with his estranged brother (a particularly cringe-inducing sequence that seems to have no purpose other than to instill boredom), and coats himself in blood and sweat. Finally, when it seems like the screenwriters have run out of scenarios, they end the film. In that sense, it plays out like a Looney Tunes cartoon, with the villains trying different and disconnected strategies to finish Rama off, only to have Rama to counter with his fists. Once the shock factor wears off, the film becomes painfully repetitive. There is a subplot involving the Lieutenant, but it's trite and forgettable.Perhaps the best scene in the film, the only one that connects it to the viewer, is that one minute of romance, when Rama, disoriented and confused, stops for a moment and imagines his pregnant wife. That scene reflects the humanity that the rest of the film is so desperately in need of. We try to focus on Rama, but by the actions of the screenwriters and the non-stop action, he is less a character than he is a bloody plot device.The action scenes are well done, the acting is nothing to be ashamed of, but the film itself, despite almost fulfilling its promise of 99 minutes of carnage, is a colossal bore.

Entertaining action movie with a very predictable story and not much we haven't already seen.Lots of hand to hand combat, a bit of shooting. Sure, a must see for martial arts fans. I'm not sure about none hardcore martial arts fans like me.The acting is good (at least dubbed), the action is there, but the movie left me half way, after 15 of 20 policemen are already dead and the story is explained though obvious hints to the audience. After that the movie just dribbles through very long fist fighting and even less story than before.The raid felt to me like someone wanted to create a movie about pencak silat and had to come up with a mafia-like story to wrap around it. It's sad that only one of the 20 policemen is able to "use" pencak silat while the others are just there to feed the story but need to die quickly so Iko Uwais can shine...that's actually very American and I don't like it.Seeing so many 8-10* reviews I expected much more. It's only a 6* to me.

reviews.review_title: Holy Sht that is a terrible movie!
reviews.content: The fight scenes initially are kinda cool, but then after the 35th identical fight scene, you sort of just become numb to the whole thing. The acting is BAD, except the main character that is a good guy. He's decent. But WOW, the rest of the actors are awful!! I don't really blame them though, the movie has no plot so speak of, and what little plot it has is so damn predictable it mine as well not have one at all. The movie was not character driven though and there is very little dialogue. Wait, the movie is not story driven either.. Come to think of it, this movie has no point, no drive, and no reason to watch it. I cannot emphasize this enough, RAID sucks!! Yo, Gareth Evans, you owe me two hours of my life back!!!

Pros: 1. Excellently timed action 2. Fantastic fighting scenes, somewhat realistic (fighting, not the shooting) 3. Incredible level of violence 4. Superbly brutal executions and deathsCons: 1. Horrible acting 2. Shallow characters 3. Laughable story 4. Borderline idiotic SWAT teamThe Raid: Redemption has the ability to pump you up with adrenaline while watching it's impressive fighting scenes, but also has a tendency to make you laugh with the stupidity of a professional SWAT team. If you're searching for impressive acting, character development, superb story or story twists, look elsewhere, but if you're in for some brutal executions and incredible martial arts, then I suggest you watch this movie.

It felt like I was watching a very violent version of pornography. What else was there except "extreme violence"? I'm not sure if I can call this an action movie or just a non-stop machete slaughter. The story line wasn't built well enough to explain all the extreme bloodshed. Effects were pretty good, but it was only to make the scenes look even more gruesome. Maybe it was based on some kind of a computer game, and kids these days follow what's more provocative. Then they have youtube or thousands of other private websites that are up for only violent scenes. Movie making involves building characters, writing a proper scenario, and decent acting too. It should also involve social responsibilities as to how they may influence the viewers, especially young or psychologically unstable ones. The more shocking fact is that this movie now got 7.8, so I had to do something. Cheers! Let's make movies and stay sane!

reviews.review_title: For those who gave high rating to this movie.. You haven't seen any good action movies!!!
reviews.content: To begin with, I can't believe those high rating and reviews, specially that one who wrote the best action film he's ever seen (clearly he has not seen anything). This movie has a lot of problems, specially when they make a retard special force team, i get that the story was that they get wiped out, but they looked so terrible, dying in every stupid way. I have seen plenty of military tactic movies, if you think that was good, i feel sorry for you. Also about the fighting style, I learned that was Indonesian Pencak Silat, but it was rather slow and predictable moves, nothing like old school Hong Kong martial art movies that comes with a variable of fighting style. One of the final scene when they face Mad Dog, he was UNKILLABLE, at one point I got bored and can't believe all the critical hit he took and he kept going, the fight got too long and lost its sense, it should have ended at one point when he got a tube stuck to his jugular, I mean, come on! Losing blood like that and he kept fighting like nothing? I normally don't write a review but I had to here because I can't believe all those people with the high rating.. I watched all the old school martial art movies, specially 70,80,90's Hong Kong Kung fu movies and all the other military tactical films, this one just gave me a face-palm.

reviews.review_title: Worst SWAT team I've ever seen
reviews.content: I 've seen many police and SWAT stories in movies and they're OK, but this one is the worst. When you raid a place don't let people hinder your team because every seconds count. The first few minutes...OK I'll pass it on, but later the bad guys are more smarter than the SWAT team who spent long hours of training. This is one of the most exciting movies I've seen in the new millennium. Gareth Evans camera moves with such stylish ingenuity, the editing is flawless, creating smooth jumps between expertly choreographed action, and never leaving a jarring cut to interrupt the flow.The story and script are simple, serving only to show us violence and fantastically crafted action. It doesn't jump for higher pretensions and indeed it doesn't have to.The acting is fine, filled with serious faces about to about to smash in more serious faces. But their martial arts is welcoming and everyone puts in good effort.The production design is excellent. Not only the editing, but the blood, the stylish cinematography employing all manner of "cool" aerial shots, interesting lenses, and the way the camera effortlessly follows the action and body movement: a marvelous gun ballet. The colours however are boring and muted, but Gareth Evans makes good use of shadows throughout to make a truly professional, even Hollywood big-budget looking film.The Indonesian martial arts are put on good display and mixed with the bluntness of the violence, introduces the viewer to something brutal, pragmatic, but visually entertaining violence, free from the wires and dance fighting of wuxia.An exciting bullet ballet.

I had heard great things about this film. I had read some gushing reviews and had friends tell me how fantastic it was.I just don't see it. There is a paper thin "plot", and the fight scenes are incredibly repetitive. If you enjoy watching Pro Wrestling, this is probably the film for you. The film contains a lot of highly scripted "dance" martial arts where the baddies run at the good guy one at a time, and get beaten to a bloody pulp with a serious of highly unrealistic martial arts moves that really fail to convince. There are lots of bits where the good guy gets knocked to the floor, and instead of getting beaten to a mangled mess as would happen in real life by a competent opponent, he does one of those kicks from his back to the leg of his opponent, that looks about effective as a flick to the ear, but miraculously this leads to the assailant being sent hurtling though the air, doing a few back flips, and then crashing to the floor unconscious/dead. Well, that's a slight exaggeration but you know what I mean I'm sure... Its all just over the top, hard to believe, nonsense. It is dance, not combat.However, maybe that's the point and perhaps this reviewer is a little jaded from over-exposure to real-life competitive combat in mixed martial arts, and thus the dance fighting in these types of films just doesn't work for me anymore. I accept this is a real possibility.Anyway I was thoroughly bored for most of this film, but in saying that, I did actually finish it, which is something at least. If you are interested in set-piece, unrealistic, fight scenes, where the hook is the talent of the choreographers and the performers (IE the type of stuff you get in Pro wrestling), then this film might impress you. However, if you want an engaging plot, story, realistic action and characters that you can buy into and believe, then just save yourself 90 minutes and give this one a miss.

I somewhat naively agreed to see this movie with my partner. He loves martial arts and action movies. I enjoy cinema generally, especially foreign films, and usually don't mind fun action movies that skimp a little on plot. The Raid, however, was 2+hrs of my life that i will sadly never get back. I found the incessant, meaningless violence (with complete lack of plot or character development) totally nauseating. The only reason I wasn't bored was because I felt physically ill and entirely bewildered by the lack of plot, horrific brutality and gore. I kept waiting for the scene to change and the intensity to fluctuate and the story to develop.....but instead, it was as if I had to watch the same scene on replay (albeit with a different talented stuntman and slightly changed-up weapon and bone-slicing, liver- piercing, brain-splattering moves...). I can appreciate the talented stunt-men and the impressive camera-work involved but the pros ended there for me and these were entirely cancelled by the mind-numbing brutality and lack of depth. I am aware that I'm probably one of the few females to review (and quite possibly see) this movie. Some might say I'm too 'sensitive' and 'delicate' to appreciate such an intense 'action' movie. In reply, I'd say I'm proud to be so. I am glad i still view extreme violence as ugly and degenerate (not something to admire or be excited by). I am a little concerned for those who enjoy such incessant brutality and gore. I am an ER nurse (so I care for car accident and stabbing victims in real life and see blood everyday). I watch fantasy/fictional films to be transported and elevated from my every day existence. The Raid, however, I found neither thought- provoking, exciting nor enriching. I was just left confused and thankful it had ended.

This film will raise the interest in Indonesian martial arts, called Silat. This is just a simple, yet awesome reason to watch this movie.The film start fast. After just a few minutes from start, it drops into an automatic rifle combat, witch will touch the hearts of old Counter Strike players. The second half of the movie, is almost purely about Indonesian martial arts show. Maybe this sounds negative to some of you, but you need to see this yourself. You will find a move complexity, that you've been waiting for, since The Matrix. Intesity of melee fighting scenes, is more brutal and detailed, than everything I've seen in similar movies. Unfortunately, there is a major problem with these scenes. This is also the reason why the movie gets only 8/10 from me. Most of the actors and stuntmen, are extremely professional fighters, witch is a good thing. Some scenes and execution moves are simply jaw-dropping. Make no mistake, each and every fight scene is phenomenal. The problem is that a human body, simply cannot take this amount of damage. In every scene, everyone takes massive attack. Even one simple kick of these guys, would take down an ordinary person. However, the movie operates with very long scenes, where the bad guys are really hard to beat. Sometimes it feels simply impossible, when actor X can still stand up, after taking such bone cracking hits. Fortunately, actors keep using the environment and surrounding objects, so the diversified combat will make you forget, that you should'nt believe what you see.As you may assume, focusing this hard on never ending action, takes away the storytelling. But thanks to the great cinematography, we don't really care why all this is happening. The reason for the whole raid, is absolutely irrelevant till the very end of the movie. Photograpy and audio composition is simply great. The camera changes to another at exactly the right time. Every fighting scene filmed from many different, cleverly used angles. Some non-fighting scenes are also close to artistic. Moderate lighting, mixed with a grey overall color tone, are also very useful to keep up the feeling of stress. As mentioned, the music is also a big plus. The soundtrack is a great mix of drum & bass, punk rock and electronic tracks.As an overall conclusion, The Raid is a must see for everyone who likes action films. In the huge crowd of nowadays, ultra-gigantic budgeted CGI movies, this is a refreshing, sometimes illogical but definitely entertaining movie.

This movie without a doubt is one of the most exhilarating and exhausting action movies I have ever watched. The action set pieces are incredible and the sheer amount of moves pulled off and blows delivered is truly remarkable. A massive kudos to all those involved behind the scenes and the actors themselves for giving such physical performances. Having said that belief does need suspended as some of the people in this film really do seem indestructible. For me some of the fight scenes towards the end did start to drag for me. It also had all the usual and predictable trappings of most action movies but guess that's hard to escape when doing this style of film. Overall a solid 6/10 and I'd probably watch it again.

reviews.review_title: Full action packed movie, awesome martial arts choreography, yet dull storyline
reviews.content: The Raid offers you intense non-stop full action and awesome stylish martial arts choreography featuring extreme relentless bloody violence. You wouldn't found any significant plot here, in other words there's nothing to tell about the storyline. Once you have decided to watch this movie, leave your brain outside the cinema's door and enjoy the fighting.Probably, not everyone will enjoy scene-by-scene fightings without essential supporting storyline -which is, probably The Raid was never designed to provide that since the beginning-. What I can say, this kind of movie perhaps has its own specific audiences. If you are amongst of them, you should RATE The Raid with 9 AT THE LEAST!!To think again, Gareth Evans, the director probably wants us to leave our brain outside the cinema's door, don't analyze anything, don't ask what's behind the story, just enjoy the non-stop actions and The Raid will make you hold your breath for more than 60 minutes!!!I am, exactly, not amongst of those. I'm an audience who enjoy the balanced action movie, deep storyline and strong action. But once I know what kind of movie The Raid is, as I said, I set my expectation, change my perspective, therefore I enjoyed watching the movie whilst holding my breath on!! :D

I watched this with some friends not long ago and, to be honest, I wasn't expecting a lot. I was told that it was in Japanese or another foreign language, so I would have to get by understanding the story by reading the subtitles. Now I quote from the Hobbit : "I have never been so wrong in all my life!". The film was awesome! From the moment the group of soldiers were trapped inside the block and the order to kill them came over the loudspeakers, I was really anticipating what would happen next. I absolutely loved it! The action throughout, which would have made a normal Hollywood movie very boring, seemed to fit perfectly with the film, making it one of my favourite movies of the 21st century! The fight scenes were very realistic, and even had me and my friends flinching when something particularly nasty happened to somebody. It made me fell as though I was part of the movie, and I was really exhilarated when it ended.If there is one improvement I could suggest, it would be some of the twists in the storyline- the fact that the group were able to get into the building so easily (seeing as it had been run by mobsters) was unrealistic and also, why did the sharpshooters only take out the cameos when they were looking out of a window, and not the main character, when he was? However, the film was a great success (certainly better than some Hollywood movies I've seen) and I would highly recommend it to the older ages of today's generation.

reviews.review_title: Wall to Wall violence, but lacking in heroic distinction...THere's good against evil, and then there's watching someone beat a load of people up...
reviews.content: A succession of admittedly well choreographed fight scenes, in an over-gritty, computer game like scenario. The opening scenes play out like nothing more than an elaborate, and well-filmed shoot-em-up, and the first twenty minutes or so are full of fairly standard gung-ho macho gun worship, and bang-bang action, of the sort that isn't remotely "realistic" - it focuses far more on over-elaborate squibs and gore effects than anything else. Once the guns are down, and Rama is taking on hordes of bad guys, then the film really takes off. However, we never quite leave behind the feeling of a slightly murky tightrope walk, between immorality, and just plain brutality. There's nothing heroic about "The Raid"'s fight scenes, and instead, there is little more than a grass roots heroism about the main character, which serves to justify the carnage that ensues.Fight scenes unfold with a rapidity and intensity that is dynamic, but often or not, they are built round rather complex, or unusual "gags", or set pieces, and have little internal rhythmn of their own, which is why the best fight scenes are generally the short ones - when Rama goes up against the machete gang, or the dozen or so thugs in the first hallway. The end fight is gruelling indeed, and its' finale is another piece of gritty bloodshed, which never quite feels right, coming form the hero.Traditional martial arts films - arguably, this film takes the "Game of Death" pagoda concept, and plonks it down in the middle of an urban, decayed environment - were about good people going up against scum, and handing them their butts. This feels more like a survival film, and the heroism is all but gone from the blandly idealistic Rama (well acted, but generally, rather conflicted in the scripting process), so instead, it's difficult to fully feel that we're on his side. It's a story which pares itself down to the absolute minimum, and its' attraction, its' selling point, is that it features realistic looking fight scenes, in an intense, and simplistic setting, without using the dreaded wirework, or CGi. It does this, indeed, but rather than over the top choreography, its' the intensity of its' wall to wall bloodshed that feels rather unrealistic. The movie's aesthetic is down and dirty, with both heroes and villains employing functional, but ugly fighting moves. It features impressive stuntwork definitely, however, and the fights are arguably as good looking as anything seen in films these days, but it's rather too unnecessarily bleak and bloody for its' own good - with a storyline of such comic-book simplicity, the over the top nature of the spaltter and dismemberment becomes rather wearing, and, far from feeling exciting, tends to be dwelt upon with a fetishistic zeal and attention, that makes you wonder just where the director's sympathies lie: with the idealistic, but brutal hero, or with the massacring psychopaths that he goes up against. Entertaining, it does what it sets out to do, but you could wish for a little more icing, and a little less grit, on your cake, than this.
